sp.p: I can sing none, but one about hunting; I learn'd it of Nick Stitch the Cobler in Shrewsbury; a very merry Fellow I'll say't, and had the purest roaring voice, 'twas louder than any Pack of Dogs i'th' Country; but for my part, I could never come up to him, as a Man may say.

sp.speaker: Sir Law.
sp.p: 'Sbud no more prating, but Sing, as a Man may say; thou art as hard to be got to't, as a good Singer indeed, come start fair, three hems, and away.

div.stage: Solon hems, and then sings a Song.

lg.head: I.
lg.l: TAntivee, tivee, tivee, tivee, high and low,
Hark, hark, how the merry merry Horn does blow
As through the Lanes and the Meadows we go;
As Puss has run over the Down:
When Ringwood, and Rockwood, and Jowler, and Spring,
And Thunder and Wonder made all the Woods ring,
And Horsemen, and Footmen, hey ding, a ding, ding,
Who envies the Splendor and State of a Crown.

lg.head: II.
lg.l: Then follow, follow, follow, follow, Iolly Boys,
Keep in with the Beagles now whilst the Scent lies,
The fiery-fac'd God is just ready to rise;
Whose Beams all our Pleasure Cotrouls,
Whilst over the Mountains and Valleys we rowl,
And Watt's fatal knell in each hollow we Toll,
And in the next Cottage top off a brown Bowl,
What Pleasure like Hunting can cherish the Soul.

sp.speaker: Sir Lawr.
sp.p: By the Parliament, very well Sung, I'm serious, what say you, Madam?

sp.speaker: L. Subtle.
sp.p: Old Doting Fool.

sp.speaker: Beren.
sp.p: Oh! Solon has perform'd to a Miracle, Sir.

sp.speaker: Darew.
sp.p: Oh here's Callow, and come I hope to call 'em hence, and then I'm resolv'd to attack her for all her dodging Aside.

sp.speaker: Margery.
sp.p: What ail'th ' the man? Let me alone, will ye— pish, be quiet, do I meddle with you now,— O Lord.

sp.speaker: Callow.
sp.p: She's skittish here, but she stood tame enough when we were alone within, burn me.

sp.speaker: Margery.
sp.p: Madam, the meat hath thood upon the Thable above thith quarter of hour; my Aunt Bumfiddle freth, becauth the Porrith i●h cold; the hath eat two whole Rowlth of Bread already, and vowth if you don't come presently, the will fall too without ye— Oh Lord, the man's mad I think.

sp.speaker: L. Subtle.
sp.p: Oh we'll asswage my Lady's anger with another Bumper, come Captain.

sp.speaker: Sir Law.
sp.p: Lead 'em in Boys, quick, quick— pox o'this Captain, what makes he so ready at her? Solon goes to take Berenice, and Darewell gets her hand first.

sp.speaker: Solon.
sp.p: Well, well, tho' he has snap'd ye before me, you have my good will, as a man may say. Exeunt all but Darewell and Berenice.

sp.speaker: Berenice.
sp.p: Well, Captain, you are in your Road still, you will board, I see, any thing you take to be a Prize.

sp.speaker: Darewell.
sp.p: There is no other dealing with you but violence, you use my heart worse than a Pirate would an utter Enemy, and put more chains than a Christian Slave has in the Turkish Bilboes— what did you mean by this Letter? why d'ye use me thus barbarously?

sp.speaker: Beren.
sp.p: I have sworn not to a●gue the case with you, but go to that Window and call my Woman, she shall tell ye all in three words, whilst I sit down here with a heavy heart and rest my self.

sp.speaker: Darew.
sp.p: Your Woman tell me?

sp.speaker: Beren.
sp.p: Ay, ay, my heart's too full— call Pimpwell there.

sp.speaker: Darew.
sp.p: Mrs. Pimpwell, Mrs. Pimpwell.

sp.speaker: Beren.
sp.p: Louder, louder. He turns his back to call, she rises and runs out.

sp.speaker: Darew.
sp.p: Why Mrs. Pimpwell, where the Devil are ye? a Plague on her, she's got into the Pantry, I warrant, with the Butler, or somewhere or other— how now— what gone, this is another of her damn'd freaks by Heaven! oh, the insupportable plagues a Man must run through that is debauched by that hellish vice called Love; and of a Woman too, who of all the Creation least deserves it, love your Horse, the Creature shall serve ye faithfully, and sometimes when you are drunk (and consequently not well in your sences) shall carry ye home to your house in safety; love your Dog, he shall guard your House from Thieves, and gratefully return it a hundred ways; but love a Woman, she shall like the first, hourly sting you with her Serpent subtilty, and for one minute's joy, give ye a thousand vexations; Well, she's a Fortune, that's some amends, and if I can but marry her, which by way of Revenge I hope I shall, I'll make her mind her business between Decks, she shall lower her Topsail, I warrant her. Exit.

div.head: SCENE II.
div.stage: Enter Sir Philip dress'd like a Lawyer, and Lovewell.

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.p: This, my dear Lovewell, is a rare contrivance, and I think the dress exact, but art thou sure the Fool will come and bring the Writings.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p:
Most certainly, I heard the Widow give him private Orders this Morning, thinking it more sence to trust him, being a Lover and a Stranger to you, than any relation or Friend whatsoever; I heard her tell him too, where the Councellours's Chamber was, and what hour she would have him go,
nay I have watch'd and stuck as close to 'em as their skins, i'faith.

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, 'tis excellent; but how if this damn'd Lawyer should be found?

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Oh, I have prevented that, for I immediately contriv'd a Letter as from a certain great Lady at Kensington, who being very sick, and having heard of his Honesty and Reputation, desired him to come and make her Will, the Lawyer surprised, immediately hurrys away, upon which I presently hir'd a Fellow to stand at the stair foot, and describing the Fool with the Writings, ordered him to be sent to this Tavern to you, ha, ha, ha, is not this well managed?

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.p: A Miracle, faith, my Dear, dear witty she Machiavil, how shall I make thee amends?

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: You know how, Sir, and when I have given ye a Fortune, I shall then presume to make my claim— how now?

sp.speaker: Drawer.
sp.p: There's a Gentleman below in a Coach asks for Councellor Splutter.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Oh, that's well, prithee send him up, 'tis he, I knew Exit Drawer. he would be punctual— here, here, take these Papers and be doing, you a Lawyer and without Papers in your hand, sit down, and put a face of business as if you staid for some body; quick, quick, I must vanish— but when you have got 'em, remember. Exit.

sp.speaker: Van Grinn.
sp.p: Are you Councellour Splutter, pray Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.p: My name is Splutter, Sir, which said 40 Acres lying and being—

sp.speaker: Van Grinn.
sp.p: And I warrant canst splutter like a Devil too, if thou art well greas'd ha, ha, ha, ha, very good jest faith, he has a rare plodding dull face— I warrant him, a good Lawyer, ha, ha, ha, well, I've a little business with ye, Sir, if you're at leisure.

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.p: Please to sit down, Sir? my Service t'ye— Drinks.

sp.speaker: Van Grinn.
sp.p: With all my heart, Sir, ha, ha, ha, gad I like him better and better, he's a good honest toping drunken Toad too— this is a fellow fit for business—

sp.speaker: Sir Phi●.
sp.p: Now, Sir, your pleasure. Folds up the Writings.

sp.speaker: Van Grinn.
sp.p: Why then, Sir, my pleasure is— to drink first, ha, ha, ha, a very good jest, faith.

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.p: Oh, Sir, good reason—

sp.speaker: Van Grinn.
sp.p: You'l excuse me, Mr. A— ha, ha, ha,— I've a light heart, but come to the business, you knew Sir Solomon Subtle I suppose?

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.p: Very well, Sir, alas poor Gentleman, he died lately at Haniburgh, his Lady is my Client and intimate Friend, I expect every day the Writings of his Estate to be sent me.

sp.speaker: Van Grinn.
sp.p: Let me kiss thee then, my dear limb of the Law, whilst I inform thee that here they are in this Box, ha, ha, ha, ha,— and so here's to thee again.

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.p: 'Dslife, come so soon, this will be rare news to Sir Philip Freewit, for as I hear, he is the chief Executor, he expects to have most of the Mony, but yet if my Lady pleases—

sp.speaker: Van Grinn.
sp.p:
She does please, my dear dagled Gown, ha, ha, ha, a very good
jest again, faith, if thou canst but find a flaw in the Will, five hundred Pounds are thine, my dear Wax squeezer.

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.p: Oh, there shall be a flaw, let her never doubt, Sir, we Lawyers like Tinkers, if we find no crack, can make one.

sp.speaker: Van Grinn.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, ha, why that's very well said too, faith and troth— gad I'll kiss thee again for that, and beg thy pardon heartily for doubting thy abilities; a plump cheek'd Rogue— gad he puts me strangely in mind of a little plump dutch Strumpet of my acquaintance, ha, ha, ha, well but hark thee, my dear Law-driver, dost thou know me, hah?

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.p: No faith, Sir, but I suppose you're a man of Quality?

sp.speaker: Van Grinn.
sp.p: I've 1500 a year, that's Quality enough, faith and troth, my father was but a Slop-seller, but if he had liv'd, he had been a Senator for all that, so that I've resolv'd to strike up to this Widow with a whew i'faith, ha, ha, ha,— And hark thee, hark thee, dear Cook upon Littleton, shall we chouse this silly Knight, hah?

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.p: I'll rout him utterly, Sir, I'll not give him a Groat for his Executorship; if I do not show him a Law trick that shall make him stare again, I'll give you leave to vouch this Miracle of us, that a Lawyer refus'd to get Five hundred pounds through a squeamish fit of his Conscience.

sp.speaker: Van Grin.
sp.p: Troth that would be a Miracle indeed, ha, ha, ha, here's a Bumper to thee, prithee why dost thou not laugh; gad, I could laugh methinks till I was as fat as my Lord, my Lord, as my Lord, I say, prithee be merry; what do you Lawyers never laugh?

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.p: Never, Sir, when we intend to cheat any Body, that's our Rule.

sp.speaker: Van Grin.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha,— a very good Jest, again, faith;— I'gad, thour't an admirable Person, and there are the Writings for thee— and another kiss into the bargain, Faith;— gad there's another leer so like my Dutch Strumpet again, the Rogue begins to inflame me.

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.p: Well, Sir, I'll take care of 'em.

sp.speaker: Van Grin.
sp.p: Wilt thou,— gad I hope to see thee a Judge, thou hast a notable rising Face, and the credit of this business will bring thee into plaguie Practice? Come, prithee let's drink and laugh, ha, ha, ha,— prithee laugh now.

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.p: With all my Heart, faith I've a merry fit comes upon me just on th' sudden;— I'll kiss you now, Sir, Kisses him.

sp.speaker: Van Grin.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, ha, a very good Jest, faith, ah my deer little plump Dutch Whore, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, ha, my dear Fat Flanderkin,— Fool.— Aside.

sp.speaker: Van Grin.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, ha, Well, next the Widow, Hug and kiss each other. I love thee better than any one in England, faith, I'll be hang'd if thou hast thy fellow in all the Inns of Court, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.p: Nor you in all Flanders, ha, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Van Grin.
sp.p: My dear, dear, Bill and Answer, here's a Bumper to thee; Breaks the Glass. Pox o'th' Glass; come let's take another Room, for I'm resolv'd to tope t'other Bottle with thee, ha, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.l: March on Pompey, I'll follow, ha, ha, ha.
sp.stage: Here they both stand and laugh at one another, then Exit Van Grin.
sp.l: So, here they are, and here the great feat is done,
Easily now the Widow may be won,
For what's a Widow when her Fortune's gone?

div.head: SCENE I.
div.stage: Enter L. Subtle, Berenice, and Van Grin.

sp.p: OH, undone, lost, ruin'd, beyond all possibility of a Recovery, I find now by his s●nseless Description, that this Devil Freewit, has put a Trick upon him, and got the Writings in spite of me.

sp.speaker: Beren.
sp.p: 'Tis even so, the Knight it seems own'd it just now in a Bravado to the Lieutenant, with a design to have it told you again.— Min heer Flanderkin there, has been over-reach'd by a meer Lawyer's Gown, the very shadow of Knowledge has done his business.

sp.speaker: Van Grin.
sp.p: Ha, ha, now can I hardly forbear laughing, for all I have done such a Mischief;— Why, who the Devil could imagine, that an honest Toping, Laughing Fellow as he seem'd to be, should prove a false Brother, 'gad I took him to be as errant a Lawyer as ever took Fee on both sides, or eat a Mutton Commons in the Temple:— Mutton Commons, ha, ha, ha, a very good Jest, I'faith, I can't forbear for the Soul of me.

sp.speaker: L. Subt.
sp.p: Sot, Monster, Fool; oh, where were my Brains too, that I could imagine one of that Nation guilty of the least Discretion: Thou stupid Dolt, with less Sense in thee than a crawling Insect in your Muddy Fens, a Flesh-fly in the depth of Winter, or a Mite in a Holland Cheese.

sp.speaker: Van Grin.
sp.p: 'Gad I can't forbear laughing for all that, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: L. Subt.
sp.p: Bring me a Glass of Water, my Heart's so full of Rage, it has burnt me up to a Cinder.

sp.speaker: Beren.
sp.p: This Fellow is certainly the species of a Baboon, and I warrant has a Tayl under his Clothes; I'de give a Guinny to have him search'd.

sp.speaker: L. Subt.
sp.p: A Baboon, 'dslight, thou hast nam'd the Prince of Brutes to him; this thing is one of Nature's foul-false Births, the Eye of Providence slept when he was born, and his dull Mother at his vile Conception, had nothing in her Mind but drivelling Ideots, dull Asses with long Ears, unthinking Swine, with all the other Soul-less, Lumpish Animals, the very Scum and Dross of the Creation.

sp.speaker: Van Grin.
sp.p: The Widow Railes, like a Devil to day, ha, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: L. Sub●.
sp.p: But to what purpose do I wast my Lungs, and call him Fool that ●m a worse my self, the veriest, veriest Ideot of the two,— a Widow, 'dsdeath, and let a Man out-wit me; ridiculous to Nature, nay, get my Writings too, the very Soul and Life-blood of a Widow;— Oh, I could tear my Flesh, burn, stab, or poyson, do any Mischief, and to any Creature, but to a Man much more with fiercer Vigour, and could I get the Heart of this damn'd Freewit, methinks I could with greater pleasure tear it, and with more Joy could feed or my Revenge, than Teeming Women on the long'd for Fruit, their Souls des●t t'indulge their unborn Infants.

sp.speaker: Bias.
sp.p: So I see she's here, and pox on't, now I'm put up briskly.

sp.speaker: Beren.
sp.p: This Fool comes in a rare time, he's like to be well us'd.

sp.speaker: Bias.
sp.p: Madam, I suppose you are not ignorant what I saunter about here for; My Father, I suppose, has told you what I would be at; and now I'm come my self in person, and I protest left the best Game at All Fours just now when I was within one of up, that ever I had in my life,— because my Father told me, you were at leisure, and this was the what d'ye call it, the Cricketty Minute, a Minute when they say a Woman can deny a Man nothing; besides, I love Cricket hugely, Madam, and if you please to throw your Heart towards me.

sp.speaker: L. Subt.
sp.p: No, but I will throw a thing more proper, I will throw this at your Head, Buffoon; hark'e, Puppy, get thee out of my sight, and quickly, or by all that's good, I'll beat thee. Throws a Cushion at his Head.

sp.speaker: Van Grin.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, ha.—

sp.speaker: Bias.
sp.p: I beg your Pardon, Madam,— what a Plague did my Father make a Fool of me for, this is none of the Cricketty Minute.

sp.speaker: L. Subt.
sp.p: Confusion seize all Fools; oh I'm all in Flame.— Drinks.

sp.speaker: Beren.
sp.p: Here comes t'other Booby, this will make her Mad.

sp.speaker: Solon.
sp.p: Madam, because I'm young Man, and a little awker'd in matters of Love, as a Man may say; and my Mistress there, too, being a little Cruel, and Hard-hearted, my Father sent me to desire your Ladyship to speak a good word for me, because I can't do't for my self, as a Man may say; but for all that, as I hope to be sav'd, I'm up to the Ears in—

sp.speaker: L. Subt.
sp.p: Water, ye Blockhead, ye Owl. Throws the Water in's Face.

sp.speaker: Solon.
sp.p: O Lord, Murther, Murther, I'm drown'd.

sp.speaker: Beren.
sp.p: Alas, poor Solon, has she cool'd thy Passion?

sp.speaker: Van Grin.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, he shall be called Solon the Wise no more, but Solomon the Wise, now the Widow has new Christen'd him,— ha, ha, ha, a very good Jest, Faith.

sp.speaker: L. Subt.
sp.p: There's something for you too.— Throws the Glass at him. Oh, you need not have stoop'd, Sir, it could never have hurt your Scull;— A Bullet can't do it, to my knowledge.
What a mischievous thing 'tis, when 'tis angry, ha, ha, ha.—

sp.speaker: Solon.
sp.p: The Devil take making of Love if this be the fruits on't, to spoil one's Crevat and ones Clothes, this is down-right Malice, as a Man may say.

sp.speaker: L. Subt.
sp.p: Sirrah, speak one syllable more of Love here, and I'll make my Foot-men souse thee over Head and Ears in the Horse-pond.

sp.speaker: Bias.
sp.p: This is none of Solon's Cricketty Minut●s neither, I ●i●d.

sp.speaker: Sir Law.
sp.p: I hope my Sons, Madam, have made their Merits so well known now, and their Interest with ye, is so great, that when my Grey Hairs shall fall to the ground.—

sp.speaker: L. Subt.
sp.p: As they shall presently, ye old Dotard. Pulls off his Peruke.

sp.speaker: Beren.
sp.p: The Devil's in her now, there's no hindring her.

sp.speaker: L. Subt.
sp.p: 'Dslife, get thee gone and take thy Cubs from my sight, or I will use ye all so like Fools.

sp.speaker: Van Grin.
sp.p: Look, look, she has discover'd my poor Uncle's Bald pate again, too, the Devil's in the Widow to day, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Sir Law.
sp.p: How's this, my Son Bias confounded, my Son Solon in disorder, and my self unseemly treated? What d'ye mean by this, Madam? I never was so affronted in my life, never since I was born, by the Parliament, now I'm serious.

sp.speaker: Solon,
sp.p: Mean, I care not what she means, not I, I'm sure she us'd me scurvily, and I'll bear it no longer; zookers, my Blood rises at her damnably,— I'll lay her Toppings in the Dust, come on't what will; she may be as bald as you, for ought I know, Father when her Toppings are off; Let me come to her, 'zooks, now my Blood's up, I've as devilish a Spirit as she, as a Man may say.

sp.speaker: Bias.
sp.p: No, prithee Brother Solon let her alone for this time; hark'e in thy Ear, when I've Married her, I'll revenge thee, and beat her my self.

sp.speaker: Beren.
sp.p: You had better all take good Advice, and be gone; you have heard, I suppose, the reason of her Anger, Sir Philip has cho●s'd her of her Writings to day, and in the Humour she's in, 'tis ten to one but she does ye some mischief or other.

sp.speaker: Sir Law.
sp.p: The Writing's gone, and seventy thousand Duckets,— Come away, Bias, thou shalt not have her now if she would have thee.

div.stage: Enter Lady Subtle with a Pistol.

sp.speaker: L. Subt.
sp.p: Where are these Triumvirate of Fools now? You Bully Sneak, with your Brother Coddle-scul, and old Father stupid here, get you off my Ground, or I will use you so like Crows, Magpies and Jackdaws, I will do more than ever Providence did for ye,— I will put something into your Heads, something of weight, Puppies, not a word more, march [Pushes them all out, then turns to Van Grin.] And now Myn Heer Van Grin,— laugh, come laugh now;— Where's your Jest, now, hah! thou base, thou sordid cause of my Misfortunes, come give me a Jest for't, laugh, I say.

sp.speaker: Van Grin.
sp.p: Sacrament, who can jest with a Pistol-Bullet, I could not laugh, Madam, if you'd give me a Thousand pounds, Faith and Troth.

sp.speaker: L. Subt.
sp.l: Out of my sight, thou Insect, Pushes him out, and throws the Pistol on the Table.
Oh, I shall grow Mad.

sp.speaker: Beren.
sp.p: Nay then, such Instruments as these, are not very convenient.

sp.speaker: L. Subt.
sp.p: Mad, Mad, raving Mad.

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.p: And I so near ye, Madam, to claim your Griefs, and reconcile your Cares.

sp.speaker: L. Subt.
sp.p: Is there an Impudence on this side Hell like this? I'll give y'a Welcome, Sir. Goes to take the Pistol.

sp.speaker: Beren.
sp.p: Nay, not this way, Sister, I must hinder such rough Proceedings, and leave ye to make your party good with him what other way you please, draw his Sword I'm sure he won't; and a Man carries no other weapons about him that can hurt a Widow, that I know of. Exit Berenice.

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.p: What in a fury, Widow, nay then thou art not fit for the good that I intend thee; I confess I had not the Confidence to visit thee, without the Incouragement of Clarret, but three Bottles of excellent Bourdeux,— in this Pagan time where there is such an Inundation of Sloe, Sider and Cherry, has made my Tongue so Elegant, and brought my Heart into so Amorous a Condition, that methinks I could even make Love to thee, for to say truth, thou look'st damnably provoking to day.

sp.speaker: L. Subt.
sp.p: ‛Tis in vain to abuse him, therefore 'twill be Policy in me to dissemble; down swelling Heart, and Frowns convert to Smiles, and thou great Power that gav'st a Woman Cunning, let him not know the R●ncor of my Heart, but sur●eit with the flattery of my Tongue. Aside.

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.p: Sollid and thoughtful; nay, now I view your Eyes better, that downcast glance seems to discover Care; you have had no late loss, I hope, Madam, your Husband I count none, nor you neither, to my knowledge.

sp.speaker: L. Subt.
sp.p: How poor a Vice 'tis in a Man of Sense t'insult o're Womens Weakness!

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.p: How damn'd a one, 'tis in a haughty Widow to think her Sense excels all Humane kind!

sp.speaker: L. Subt.
sp.p: Well, well, you have outwitted me.

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.p: Miracle in Nature, outwitted thee, why is it possib●e? and can'st thou own it too? nay then, I'll have it Chronicl'd, that she that in defiance of mankind, arm'd with sharp Wit, and shielded with true Pride, that never spar'd a Man in her Abuses, nor fail'd to ●ilt him if she knew he lov'd her, should in the bloom of her flourishing Glory, yield up her Lawrels to Triumphant me.

sp.speaker: L. Subt.
sp.p: Why do ye call me proud? were not my Actions natural? was't fit for me to offer you my Fortune, that thought my Person not worth treating for? What Woman of my Youth, nay, without Ostentation, not common Beauty too, nor least in Wealth, could bear a slight so poor; for tho' my Husband gave ye up my Fortune, there was Consignment too, of another Blessing to accompany the Money: But you turn Marriage-hater, and your neglect calls me old, wither'd, ugly; blame me not then for striving, tho' Successless, to dash your Pride, as you to humble mine.

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.p: Ah, Widow, Widow, tho' I find your subtle Devil has par'd his Claws,— I am not now in humour to be tickl'd: Why did you jilt me, and receive another? answer that.

sp.speaker: L. Subt.
sp.p: Why did you wrong me, and get another with Child before my Face? answer me that.

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.p: Wrong you, why the Devil's in these Widows, they'l Ingross all a Man has, before he has 'em, as well as after; wrong you! what because I had a mind to use a Sample of the Grain before the heap was to be delivered in the Market; must you call this a wrong?

sp.speaker: L. Subt.
sp.p: A Mortal one; and if you are Generous, you'l right me now.

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.p: With all my Heart, and as I'm now free, and at liberty, I best can do thee Justice; which, should I marry thee, were most impossible; I need not tell ye why,— you know the reason.— Come, let's retire.

sp.speaker: L. Subt.
sp.p: Go, y'are a Devil.

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.p: You are but a Widow yet; all in good time, that Title may be alter'd too▪

sp.speaker: L. Subt.
sp.p: Why dos't thou rail at Marriage so, thou Monster?

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.p: Because I hate it, Child, that's all the Reason.

sp.speaker: L. Subt.
sp.p: Abhorr'd Impiety, to hate a Sacred Ordination, allow'd by the most Knowing of all Ages.

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.p: A gross mistake, 'twas first devi●'d for Interest by Sapless Dotards, form'd a Law, that their dull First-born Blockheads might inherit; the generative Faculty should be free, the Spirit's pall'd when 'tis confin'd to Duty, Restive and stupid, and the Product's answerable; of Old the Worthles never came by Marriage, the Bravest and the Wis●st were all Bastards; besides, from marrying a Wd●● w, Heaven defend me.

sp.speaker: L. Subtle.
sp.p: A Widow, Sir, why what's a Widow?

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.p: Why, a meer Fripperer, or Broker's Shop, that's fain to sell her Wares at second hand; yet toils to pass 'em off to Fools for new; one that's so very knowing, that she'd baulk a Youngster, and in Love's business give such violent Instructions, 'twould break the heart of a young Fool to follow; no, if I do forego my happy freedom, which, 'till I dote, I think never shall; the Grape shall first be press'd by my own hand, I'll never take the squeezings of another, I'll have a Maid, that's certain.

sp.speaker: L. Subtle.
sp.p: A Maid, thou Coxcomb, I'm asham'd of thee, dost thou pretend to be a man of sence, Learn'd in the Mathematicks of Intreague, and choose an ignorant raw aukward Maid before a Skilful Widow, oh stupidity! Go to the Garden, take green Gennitings, and set thy teeth an edge thou codled Coxcomb; or shall I fetch thee some green Goosberries, and send a Maid to keep thee Company; a whitely thing just wean'd from Jointed Baby, that opens mouth to eat, but can say nothing; such trash as this is the best fruit for Fools; a Widow, like the blushing velve● Peach, by Summer ripened, to indulge the taste, is a Regalia for a Man; Maids, green crude stuff, and only fit for Boys.

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.p: 'Tis very fine, a Lady of your Beauty and your Fortune, oh how this witty Railery becomes, well then, Boy as I am, I'll shew one manly sign, I'll mannage the Writings wisely, that I'm resolv'd on. Enter Berenice.

sp.speaker: Beren.
sp.p: Sir Philip I'm sure can do nothing, but like a man of Honour.

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.p: Oh, cry ye mercy, Madam, and Sence too, I hope, therefore thus humbly take my leave.

sp.speaker: Beren.
sp.p: Nay, but pray stay a little, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.p: Not for the World, Madam, the Widow has so maul'd me already with her great Cannon, that should I stay to engage with your small shot, I should have more holes in me, then a Dutch Man of War had in the last Engagement; and therefore, to bring my Simile a little nearer home, like a Cock that's over-match'd, I intend to shrink from the Pit before my eyes are peck'd out.

sp.speaker: Beren.
sp.p: Your eyes, why what d'ye take us for, Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.p: Two of the greatest Rarities of your kind; two that shall rally a Man to death in an hours time, without putting your self out of breath for't. Runs out.

sp.speaker: Beren.
sp.p: This is one of the oddest humours! what, I warrant you have been severe with him?

sp.speaker: L. Subtle.
sp.p: No, hang him, I broke out only a little at last, when he was preferring a Maid before me; I smother'd my rage 'till then, tho' I confess with as much pain as if I had had a sit of the stone, for he gave me not a word of satisfaction about the Writings— he designs to starve me, I'm confident, if the Law don't relieve me.

sp.speaker: Beren.
sp.p: Nay, nay, no starving Sister, you have yet a hundred pound a year to live on.

sp.speaker: L. Subtle.
sp.p: What's that? I must put down my Coach, Child, is not that starving a Widow?

sp.speaker: Beren.
sp.p: Next door too't, I confess, as the humour of the Times are.

sp.speaker: L. Subtle.
sp.p: Ah! I had rather be without meat and drink a thousand times. Well, sure this Devil won't possess him always, one happy minute must be mine at last, which to be sure of, what would I not attempt, what to obtain her Ends, would not a Woman do?

lg.l: Would Fortune once my working Brain inspire,
I'de plunge through deepest Sea, or fiercest Fire,
Hazard my Life, nay Soul, to compass my desire. Exit.

sp.speaker: Beren.
sp.p: Nay, on my Conscience, if there is a way left, thou wilt conjure, but thou wilt have it, that I'll say for thee. Well, what News now? Enter Comode.

sp.speaker: Comode.
sp.p: My Lady Bumfiddle sends ye word that my Lord Brainless gives the Musick at her Lodgings this Afternoon, before they go to the Park, and desires your Company.

sp.speaker: Beren.
sp.p: Well, I'll go, because I know I shall meet my Tarpawlin there, whom I have made so angry, that I believe he could beat me with as good a will, as a Saylor that disobey'd his Orders; 'tis all one, I am resolv'd to try him throughly, before I come under his hatches, there will be hours enough to beg his pardon, if ever I give him an advantage over me.

lg.l: The time of Wooing is a Woman's own,
But when she's Married once, her time is gone. Exit.

div.head: SCENE II. Bumfiddle's Lodgings.
div.stage: Enter Callow and Margery, at several Doors.

sp.speaker: Callow.
sp.p: Ah! dear Creature, how much am I oblig'd to Fortune for this lucky minute, that gives me the blessing of meeting her alone, whom I love beyond all the Universe, sink me!

sp.speaker: Margery.
sp.p: You love me, yeth I warrant ye, for what pray?

sp.speaker: Callow.
sp.p: For thy self, my Dear, thy Innocence and Beauty has so charm'd my heart: her Money I mean; that I never am at rest, my Soul, but when I am with thee. Aside.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Oh Lord, well then, donth queeth my hand tho.

sp.speaker: Callow.
sp.p: Oh! every part of thee is so Charming to me, that burn me, 'tis impossible for me to subsist without thee. The Philly can stand still, I see, when she is without Company. Aside.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Why, what d'ye mean to do? you won't Ravish me, will ye?

sp.speaker: Callow.
sp.p: I believe she puts me in mind on't on purpose, Rot me, Aside. Ravish thee, no, no, only a kiss from thy pretty Lips, or so, my Dear sweet Hony-suckle; nay, nay, no frowning now, nor drawing back, for I must do it, therefore— Kisses her.

sp.speaker: Marger.
sp.p: What d'ye make all this bustle for, why don't ye then?

sp.speaker: Darew.
sp.p: Oh, Lieutenant, you are a happy Man, I see.

sp.speaker: Marger.
sp.p: Oh Lord, the Captain, what shall I do now? Spets, and speaks as in a rage to Callow. Pugh, pugh, well, as I hope to be thav'd I'll tell my Father, and my Aunt, tho I will, that I can never live in quiet for ye; that you are every day teithing, and by your good will would be kithing me every minute; when you know I hate ye ath I hate the Devil, and with you were hang'd upon our Mulberry-Tree in the Garden, with all my heart; like a thilly ugly, nathly, pimping, cowardly, tholdierly, rathcally, puppily Fellow ath ye are, to dare to affront me so. Exit. Margery.

sp.speaker: Darew.
sp.p: 'Dslife, what's the meaning of all this rage? she stood ●ame enough to my thinking, when I came in.

sp.speaker: Callow.
sp.p:
Ay, and would again, if we were alone; '●is the nature of this sort ●f Cattle to be skittish, and Rail before Company, but they'l stand as still in a
Corner, as a Town Whore (got with Child by some poor Bully) will to a Rich Country Squire, that she intends shall father it: I must after her, for I like her Six Thousand Pounds better than my Commission, faith, Captain. Exit. Callow.

sp.speaker: Darew.
sp.p: Faith I believe thee, as do a great many more of thy Effeminate sort— But stay, where is my jolly Lady all this while, and the Company? sure I han't mistook her time; oh! are you there, Madam? Enter Berenice.

sp.speaker: Darew.
sp.p: Nay, you shall hear me now, and I must rail at ye, or my heart will break; call ye ungrateful, proud, false, and unnatural, not only to abuse an honest Fellow that loves ye, but glory and persist in't— Heav'n, what could you mean by this Letter, this abhor'd Invective? In a soft tone.

sp.speaker: Beren.
sp.p: This Letter has stuck in his throat worse than a Ship-bisket.

sp.speaker: Darew.
sp.p: Well, what amends for this? What satisfaction? she seems good natur'd now, and sorry for what's past, this may be the Critical minute. Aside.

sp.speaker: Beren.
sp.p: I am more sorry, Sir, then you can desire, and if you'd please, to name your satisfaction.

sp.speaker: Darew.
sp.p: This is as I could wish, I see t'has touch'd her nearly. Aside.

sp.speaker: Beren.
sp.p: I beg your pardon, Sir, with all my heart, and what else you you'll honourably Command.

sp.speaker: Darew.
sp.p: only your Love, dear Madam, that's the Prize I value beyond Empire.

sp.speaker: Beren.
sp.p: 'Tis yours from this hour, Sir.

sp.speaker: Darew.
sp.p: My Soul, Life, Heart, Blood— Ah Pox o' these Intruders, just in the nick too, when I should have clench'd the Nail I have been so long a driving— ah! 'tis impossible to proceed, now they come like a deluge.

div.stage: Enter L. Bumfiddle, L. Hockley, Mrs. Bandy, and Mrs. La Pupsey, with her Lap-Dog.

sp.speaker: L. Bum.
sp.p: Boy, bid 'em make ready the Tea, and set the Dishes in order: My Dear, your humble Servant, how d'ye good Captain, what so close together, nay, then there's something more in the wind; I must know, you'll never thrive in't else, Captain; hark'e, a word in your ●ar.

sp.speaker: Darew.
sp.p: So, now shall I be toss'd by the tempest of her tongue, worse than ever I was by a storm in the Bay of Biscay. L. Bum. whispers Darewell.

sp.speaker: L. Hock.
sp.p: I vow Mrs. La Pupsey, I never look upon your fine Dog, but it sets me almost a crying; I had the finest Bolognia Shock was drown'd t'other day, that, o' my Soul, ever lay in Lap; I carried him to the Park every night with me, the Creature had so sweet a breath, that I vow I miss it strangely.

sp.speaker: Bandy.
sp.p: 'Tis a delicate prit●y Rogue indeed, now my Mother is so cross, she'll let me have nothing to play with; I did but desire t'other day to buy a little Monkey for my Chamber, and flying out into a passion, she swore a great huge Oath, I had as lieve thou shouldst have a Man there.

sp.speaker: La. Pup.
sp.p: Go Dony, go to my Lady, and kiss her, and love her, that's my sweet Creature.

sp.speaker: L. Hock.
sp.p: Come, dear Iewel, come.— Take the Dog.

sp.speaker: La Pup.
sp.p: Did you ever see a thing so modest, and so shy in your life, Madam, here's no Courting him to a Wise; I have been this ●hree Months making a Match for him, and could never get him in humour.

sp.speaker: L. Hock
sp.p: Fy●, that's a mighty fault, indeed.

sp.speaker: La. Pup.
sp.p:
Th●n, Madam, of all Creatures Heterog●neal, he is the most— Cleanly,— no Ma●ge, for ever Impe●iginous in the least;— then he's a Miracle for his distinction in Philanthropy, he has an entire love for our Party; he
knows my Humour to a Hair; he'l not come near the Tarpawlin Captain, yonder, because he's a Williamite, 'tis a wonder to tell ye, but the Creature has a strange aversion for this Government.

sp.speaker: L. Hock
sp.p: Alas, all the Ingeniou● part of the Nation have so, Madam.

sp.speaker: Bandy.
sp.p: Well, l'vads I will have a Dog then, let my Mother say what she will;— I believe it teaches her to talk so, for I never heard such fine words in my life. Aside.

sp.speaker: Darew.
sp.p: Faith, Madam, all that I can find by your long whispering, is, that you have a mind to dine with me to morrow.

sp.speaker: L. Bu●.
sp.p: Why, what a blunt Ass art thou?— to tell me of Dining with thee; Dine with thy Mistress, Fool, and let me be by to put in a word for thee, if thou'●t wise;— depend upon me, I know her Humour to a Scruple, and if thou takest my Council, thou shall have her:— Do I talk of Dinners now?— 'tis true, a good fat Haunch of Venison, boyl'd with Colliflowers, would do well to piddle over:— Eating together begets Love: 'Twas my Husband's Venison more than himself, that first won my Heart, as I'm a Protestant.

sp.speaker: Darew.
sp.p: Well then, Madam, since you will be concerned in my Affair, be sure y'are Industrious.

sp.speaker: L. Bum.
sp.p: Keep up thy Interest with me, thou shalt have her, Boy.

div.stage: Enter L. Brainless, Singers, Musick, and Dancers.

sp.speaker: L Brain.
sp.p: Oh, Madam, your Ladyships most humble Servant, yours, yours, dear Ladies, and your most obedient Slave, dear, sweet, pretty Dony; gad I beg your Pardons, all, for being thus tardy; oh, how do's my dear Captain too? why this is a piece of a Miracle to find thee a-shore, and especially amongst the Ladies, where Musick is going forward, for I know thou hatest all these Effeminate Instruments, hark'e, shall I send to the Tower, and borrow two or three pieces of Canon to entertain the●, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Darew.
sp.p: Coxcomb.— Aside.

sp.speaker: Beren.
sp.p: Wou'd they wou'd haste and begin; that grim furly look of the Captains, will put us all out of Humour, else; what a Face is there, with a grim●ce as sower as if the Surgeon were just putting him on a Wooden-Leg.

sp.speaker: Darew.
sp.p: The Devil it is,— well, I hope you like it; however, Madam.—

sp.speaker: Beren.
sp.p: I like it, I like the Face upon that Fiddle there, better by half; I like it,— ha, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Darew
sp.p: words, Madam, Madam.

sp.speaker: Beren.
sp.p: Oh, none of your Culverin Shot here, good Captain, you had better use it against the French at Sea.

sp.speaker: Darew.
sp.p: Damn her, she's got into one of her old freaks again.

sp.speaker: L. Bum.
sp.p: Words of course, words of course, Fool, apply thy self to me; I tell thee, I'll do thy business; hark in thy ear, get the Venison ready.

sp.speaker: La. Pup.
sp.p: Why, sure the Gentleman can't be so desipient, to take any thing ill that a Lady says; Railery from a Woman, though never so severe, should be supported by every man of Sense with generous Equanimity.

sp.speaker: Darew.
sp.p: Oh, good Madam, be pleas'd to Cramp your Dog there, with your hard Phrases, and let him lick you an answer, how you please; or go and puzzle my Lord there, any one but me I bes●●eh ye.

sp.speaker: L. Pup.
sp.p:
Lick me an Answer, come Sir, I must tell ye, your Discourse has no Concatination in't, 'tis all blunt and disjoyn●ed, and, as my Lord says, your Soul
is very unmusical, that I believe you never knew a Diaphony from a Diapason.

sp.speaker: Darew.
sp.p: Nay, nay, I'll not be tongue-worried now, I've a remedy fort.— Exit.

sp.speaker: Bandy.
sp.p: Well, I swear I could live and dye with this La Pupsey, if it were only to hear her talk.

sp.speaker: L. Hock
sp.p: She excels me, I think in the Cassicks, but I was always accounted much the best Natural Philosopher.

sp.speaker: L. Brain.
sp.p: Come, Madam, now I will present you with my own Composition, which I lately told ye of, wherein I envy the joys of that happy Creature, your Dog, and passionately bemoan my own Infidelity; I was extreamly Melancholly when I writ it.

sp.speaker: La Pup.
sp.p: Where's your bow down to the ground, Dony? Your Lordships most humble Servant, says he. Enter Boy with Tea.

sp.speaker: L. Bum.
sp.p: My Lady Hockly, wilt have any Tea? Mrs Berenice, prithee come and sit by me.

sp.speaker: Beren.
sp.p: 'Tis for my Instruction, I know, Madam,— now has she some smutty Joke or other to whisper me: They sit down all.
Ay.— 'tis as I said. L. Bum. whispers.

sp.speaker: La. Pup.
sp.p: Come, my Lord, now your own, I beseech ye, I know it must be extraordinary.

sp.speaker: L. Brain.
sp.p: With all my Heart; you must know Ladies, I call it Celadon's Complaint against Monsieur Le Chien; 'tis writ like a Man of Quality, when the next new Play comes out: I intend to give it the Poet, to shew 'em the right way of making a Song: Hem, hem,—

body.head: The SONG of Monsieur Le Chien.

lg.l: GReat Jove once made Love like ● Bull;
With Li●da a Swan was in vogue,
And to persevere in that Rule,
He now does descend like a Dog;
For when I to Silvia would speak,
Or on her Breast sigh what I mean;
My Heart strings are ready to break,
For there I find Monsieur Le Chien.
2. For Knowledge in Modish Intreagues,
Or managing well an Amour,
I defie any one with two Legs,
But here I am Rival'd by sour:
Distracted all night with my wrongs,
I cry, Cruel Gods,— what d'ye mean,
That what to my Merit belongs
You bestow upon Monsieur Le Chien.
3 For Feature or Niceness in Dress,
Compare with him surely I can;
Nor vainly my self should express,
To say I am much more a Man;
To the Government firm too, as he,
(The former I cunningly mean)
And if he Religious can be,
I'm as much sure as Monsieur Le Chien.
4 But what need I publish my parts,
Or idly my Passion relate;
Since Fancy that Captivates Hearts
Resolves not to alter my Fate:
I may Sing, Caper, Ogle, and Speak,
And make a long Court ausi bien,
And yet with one passionate ●ick
I'm out-rival'd by Monsieur Le Chien.

sp.speaker: L. Bum.
sp.p: Very pretty truly, my Lord.

sp.speaker: L●. Pup.
sp.p: Pretty, 'tis incomparable, I swear, your bow to my Lord down to the ground agen, Dony. She bows, the Dog of Lord bows too.

sp.speaker: L. Brain.
sp.p: No, Faith, there's no great matter in 'em, tho' the Conceipt, truly I think is new; but now, Madam, in pursuance of French Gallantry, I hope to have the honour to see the particular entertainment you promised. Goes and talks to La Pupsey.

sp.speaker: Beren.
sp.p: Strike up Musick. A Scotch Song and Dance here.

sp.speaker: L. Bum.
sp.p: Ah, sweet Mrs. La Pupsey, what would I give to do as much; here, prithee take some Tea, 'tis good now y'are hot.

sp.speaker: La Pup.
sp.p: Tea, Madam, 'tis burnt Brandy.

sp.speaker: L. Bum
sp.p: Why, that's all the Tea in Fashion, now, Fool.

sp.speaker: L. Brain.
sp.p: ●om●, let's go to Brightsbridge Garden to Coole; Ladies, I'll retire and dress, and wait on ye there instantly; there will be all the World this fine Evening.
'Tis very true, as I'm a Protestant: come then, my dears, let's go?
Come, Dony, abroad, abroad, Dony kiss me, ye dear Jewel,— kiss, kiss. Exeunt.

div.head: SCENE III. Enter Sir Philip and Lovewel.

sp.speaker: Sings.
sp.p: Did you not promise me, &c.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: 〈◊〉 ye revoke your Promise then, can ye be so ungrateful?

sp.speaker: Sir Phil
sp.p: Prithee, my dear, no more, that I will always love thee, thou mayst assure thy self.
●ove me, and keep me like a Slave dishonour'd thus, 'tis most impossible, no, if you'd h●●e me believe you have the least Comp●ssion for me: perform your Promise, and take me for your Wife.

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.p: My Wife, then I should never love thee more.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Have I not purchas'd ye with Toyl and Study, paid with my Labour and Industrious Wit, a Ransom for repeal of my Dishonour, nay, brought ye a Fortune too beyond your hopes, the best Inducement to a Marriage state, and de'ye forget me? fye, Sir, indeed▪ you must not, you know y'are mine by bargain.

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.p: And will perform it to thee the best way, by a free, vigorous and active love, nay, if I fail thee, Child, then I were ungrateful indeed.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: You never can perform, unless you marry me.

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.p: Oh, I warrant ●hee, Child, I warrant thee.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: You know I love ye much beyond my life; you know what's due to a Vow of Honour● and tho' my tender years, and too fond Heart, charm'd by your Merit, and your graceful Person, was won too soon at first: I could not doubt your Vows, and was as innocent of doing wrong, as fearless of receiving it from you.

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.p: 'D●heart, with naming Marriage, gad thou hast also made me keck already: oh, I should make a damn'd confounded Husband; I am like those that cannot sleep with Doors and Windows shut, if I want Air I suffocate: besides, is it not better to come to thee, wanton and brisk, and aiery as a Bird, to hop into the Bosom, Sing and Bill, then fly away, soon after come again, pruning my self in welcome Liberty, than be confin'd to moulter in a Cage, and batten in the Excrement of Marriage?

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Does this Consideration Countervail my being a Whore, and my dear Boy a Bastard.—

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.p: A Bastard, why he's the more like to be a Hero, I hope; I was a Bastard my self.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: No, you design, I see, to break my Heart: ah barbarous Man, how can you be so Cruel? have I not always been most faithful to ye? can there be any Virtue in a Wife, which I'de not hourly practice to oblige ye? nay, do me but this Justice, you shall find, I'll be the dearest h●mblest of your Creatures: Say, think, do what you please, I'll be obedient, never repine or grumble at your Actions, nor say you wrong me, tho' you give cause; never expect the Pleasures that Wives covet, to gad abroad, and Riot in rich Clothes, but sit at home all day like a House-Dove, and if I have you there be glad and merry, if not, with throbbing Heart be still and Patient— my Eyes shall watch, which if some drops should fill I'll dry 'em up just as I hear you coming, and meet my Love still with a face of Joy.

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.p: Pretty Rogue, prithee no more of this sad stuff,— thou madest me sick just now with talking, and now thou makest me melancholly.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Upon my Knees I beg.

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.p: Oh fie, this carrying the humour on so far, will make me Angry, you know my Humour, and 'tis unalterable,— I'll provide for ye well, and you in reason should desire no more; and now our business is done,— you shall come away from Sir Lawrence to morrow,— but not a word more of this stuff, as you tender my Displeasure.— Marry, in the Devils name, 'd●death I'm all over in a cold Sweat at the thought on't. Exit Sir Phil.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Base and perfidious, hast thou then deciv'd me, is there no truth nor honour in the Sex, no Balmy Cure for betray'd Innocence too fondly trusting in deceitful Man?— Ah, no, I find there is not, let Cunning then, the Woman's never sailing Art assist me; once more I'll set my fruitful Brains to work,— fawn, wheedle, lye, and seem to be pleas'd, as is if he really had kept his Promise: hah, 'tis hatching here already, and I hope 'twill prosper, to redress such a wrong every just Power will Aid me:

lg.l: The very Indian Heathens hate this Ill,
They never promise more than they fulfil:
If any Virgin does her Humour trust
Her Tawny Lover, tho' he's rude is Love.:
But our worse Heathens here conspire our Ruin,
And make a jest of a poor Maid's undoing. Exit.

div.head: SCENE I.
div.stage: Enter Sir Lawrence, Solon and Bias.

sp.speaker: Sir Lawr.
sp.p: FOR an old Courtier that has liv'd in four Kings Reigns, seen three Crown'd, and had a strong hand in the late Revolution, who, tho' he has got nothing, has spent an Estate amongst 'em, and that's good sign one of a Courtier, to find in his latter days such a dearth of good Manners, as to see himself affronted, and his Progeny baffled, by a clest Canibal, a Woman; it has not only given me the Spleen, but methinks I have upon me, the Gout, the Stone, the Sciatica, and all the Distempers incident to Human frailty, through mere vexation by the Parliament.

sp.speaker: Bias.
sp.p: Well, let it be as it will, I'll be a Man or a Mouse I'm resolv'd on't, I will have a Wife somewhere or other, now my mind is set on't, let the Widow be as Musty as she pleases— what, any Man that will Marry need not want a Wife in London sure.

sp.speaker: Sir Lawr.
sp.p: No Boy, I've another in my Eye for thee, I look upon this senceless haughty Minx that abus'd us, as upon a thing of nothing, and now she's baffled of her Writings, a thing that has nothing, nor shall deserve our further trouble; for a Widow without Money, is like a Purse without it, when once she is empty she in not worth wearing.

sp.speaker: Solon.
sp.p: True, Father, or like a Nut that's Maggot-eaten, when this Kernel's gone once, the Shell is not worth cracking, as a Man may say.

sp.speaker: Sir Lawr.
sp.p: By the Parliament, and that's well said, Solon, I see this Boy has his Wit by sits and girds, as Women have their good Humors— gad, one of the old Patriarchs could not have spoke a wiser thing than that now.

sp.speaker: Bias.
sp.p: There's another Widow that I know of, that I believe has a Months mind to me, and I'll go and strike her up ere long; ' y●aith I'll make but few words with her, not I; if they wont when they may, they may let it alone for Bias,— 'tis the Widow Hockley I mean, I believe you know her, old Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Bias.
sp.p: How now,— What would this Woman have, 'tis all one, I'll have a smack at her, saith, I'll give her a touch to remember me by. Goes and kisses her rudely.

sp.speaker: Pimp.
sp.p: Rude ill-bred Fellow.

sp.speaker: Sir Law.
sp.p: Ha, ha— Did you ever see such a Mettled Rogue, this is so like me in my young days, I have done as much to my Mo●hers Dairy-Maid many a time in the Corn-●ield at home.

sp.speaker: Bias.
sp.p: Nay, never frown nor call names for the matter, here are Lads of mettl●, I can tell ye but that.

sp.speaker: Pimp.
sp.p: Prethee Fool be quiet, I have nothing to say to thee, my business is to this Gentleman. Goes t● Solon, ●e shrin●s back.

sp.speaker: Solon.
sp.p: Me ●orsooth, why I don't know ye not I, as a Man may say.

sp.speaker: Bias.
sp.p: Give her a smack, Solon, don't let her prate, give her a smack, I did Boy.
Sir, tho' I'm a stranger t'ye, I suppose you know my Mistress, Madam Berenice.

sp.speaker: Sir Law.
sp.p: Humph, Berenice.

sp.speaker: Pimp
sp.p: Who knowing ye to be in the Garden, sends word by me, that she desires to be happy in your good company.

sp.speaker: Bias.
sp.p: Smack her, I say, Solon. Come, I'll shew thee the way. Goes towards her.

sp.speaker: Sir Lawr.
sp.p: 'Dsheart, let her alone, Sirrah. Madam, your most humble Servant— my Son shall wait upon her Ladyship instantly, and I beg your pardon heartily for t others rudeness, for to say the truth, he's drunk, Madam,— I had no way but that to bring the Dog off. aside.

sp.speaker: Pimp.
sp.p: I'm satisfy'd, Sir,— come, Sir, Will ye go?

sp.speaker: Solon.
sp.p: Ay with all my heart. Really Madam, I'm overjoy'd, as a Man may say.

sp.speaker: Bias.
sp.p: Gadzooks, why this Solon's a lucky Dog now.

sp.speaker: Sir Lawr.
sp.p: Lucky, ay:— you had like to have made fine work, sie upon't: introth Bias, you must not be so rampant, you might have spoil'd your Brother's Fortune by't, by the Parliament you might, now I'm serious,— but go, d'ye hear, Comb your Peruke, and spruce your self up, the new Widow will be here presently, she's to come with my Sister Bumfiddle— go go you'll find me hereabouts. Exit Bias.

Ah, many a nights rest do these two Boys hinder me of, they're two ingenious Youths truly, at least, if I may be Judge, especially Solon, wherein I di●●et from other Fathers, who generally are ●ondest of the eldest Blockhead; now I am of the youngest: I have a Daughter too, but I think she's secure enough from the Town-Fellows, for I have neither let her Write nor Read, because she shan't understand Love-Letters: humph, by the Parliament, here she comes, and that same Rake▪ helly Lieutenant with her, Enter Callow and Margery. if this skittish lisping Jade should turn Whore now, before she can read her Horn book— the Devil must be very strong in her. I'll stand aside and observe.

sp.speaker: Callow
sp.p: To affront and abuse your humble Servant so, my dear pretty Creature, without any reason, I swear it went to my Heart.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Why, What would you have me do when the Folks thee us, I'm tho asham'd before company, I can't tell what to do, besides, if my Father should but know.

sp.speaker: Sir Lawr.
sp.p: Which, the Devils in him if he should, being so far out of the way—

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: He would never let me go abroad agen, for he hates I thould talk to a Ma● for fear I thould Marry, and oblige him to pay me a Porthion.

sp.speaker: Sir Lawr.
sp.p: Does he so, Oatmeal Face, I shall talk with you presently. aside.

sp.speaker: Callow.
sp.p: Thy Father, ah prithee don't name him, Child, as long as I have thee of my side, the old Fellow's but aCipher, besides, I out-wit him always, I lead him by the Nose when-ever I see him, Rot me.

sp.speaker: Sir Lawr.
sp.p: Very good, there's an impudent Rogue too, he has an ignorant raw skittish Head, with a Flairing Comode on, and he's an Addle Blockheaded B●lly, with a ●luttering Scarfe on, they're a mighty ●ine Couple indeed.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Nay, pish— now you squeeth me too hard agen, lord you make such a Bu●●le always, and do tho Ru●●le and tumble ones Head with kithing one.

sp.speaker: Callow.
sp.p: A thousand Pardons my dear Rogue, that's well put in my Head faith.

sp.speaker: Sir Lawr.
sp.p: Oh rare, rare doings! She can't speak at home, nor won't let a Man touch her when she's before me; but the Quean can bill like a Pidgeon, I see, now. aside.

sp.speaker: Marger.
sp.p: O my Conscience, for ought I thee you intend to marry me.

sp.speaker: Callow.
sp.p: Marry thee; Ay, what else my dear Rogue.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: O Lord, I shall never endure it, I shall cry my self to death.

sp.speaker: Sir Lawr.
sp.p: O hang ye— aside.

sp.speaker: Callow.
sp.p: What a plague does she mean? I believe she has a mind to have a touch before-hand, Sink me.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Besides, my Father will kill me.

sp.speaker: Callow.
sp.p: He, an Old Grizzle,— 'Dslife I'd banter him to death in half an hours time; and if he should but touch thee, I would give him a sillup with my two Fingers, that should knock him as ●lat as a Battle-Ax. Burn me.

sp.speaker: Sir Lawr.
sp.p: Why then Sirrah, there's a sillup to provoke ye— Come Draw, Bully, Draw— I will cut your Throat else, by the Parliament I will, I can Swear as well as you, Dogbolt.

sp.speaker: Callow.
sp.p: 'Dsheart, Sir Lawrence here; what shall I do now?

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: My Father! Now the Devil take all ill Luck— I mutht take his part— Do, do, Father— Beat him, thwinge him, break his Bones, cut his Throat, for I can never be quiet for him, like a deboath'd, drunken, doltish, dunderheaded, detheitful, damn'd, devillish Dog, as he is, to t●ith me ●ho.

sp.speaker: Callow.
sp.p: So, so; She's in the old stile again— I shall be worried between 'em if my Legs don't befriend me— Runs out.

sp.speaker: Sir Lawr.
sp.p: A Cowardly Rascal; what is he gone?— Here's a fine Scarse-Officer for ye,— if they should chance to be all such, we should beat the French finely; we should have a special Army by the Parliament.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: I believe, Sir, I have forwarned the Fellow above a Thouthand times tho I have.

sp.speaker: Sir Lawr.
sp.p: Oh, very likely; that made you cry, O Lord you make thutch a Buthle, and do tho Ru●●le ones head with kithing one,— Hah, you lithping Quean you:— But I'll manage you I'll warrant you.— Come Hussy, ●ome along with me. Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter Sir Philip, Darewell, and Van Grin.

sp.speaker: Van Grin.
sp.p: You never saw such a Fellow as I am in your life, Captain, for the more the Widow Rail'd, the more I Laugh'd, ha, ha, ha, till she fetch'd out the Pistolls, and then she made me as mute as a Fish saith; for you know there was no Jest in that; but till then, ha, ha, ha, ha, you would have dy'd with Laughing, Jest after Jest, Hit after Hit, Joke after Joke, souse upon her, as fast as Hops, you never saw such a fellow in your life, Faith and Troth.

sp.speaker: Darew.
sp.p: No the Devil take me not I, nor any one else, I believe.

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.p: I'll discover my self to the Fool, 'twill add to the Jest.

sp.speaker: Darew.
sp.p: No, prithee, not yet; let him go on a little further.

sp.speaker: Van Grin.
sp.p: But the Devilish Jest of all was, that I should give the Writings, instead of the confounded Counsellor, to this plaguy Sir Philip, ha, ha, ha, ha,— whom I never saw in my Life; but I hear he's the Devil of a Fellow.

sp.speaker: Sir Phil
sp.p: The Devil he is, and are you sure you don't know him when you see him, Min Heer Van Blunderpate.

sp.speaker: Van Grin.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, ha— Grin stares at him and Laughs

sp.speaker: Sir Phi●.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, ha—

sp.speaker: Van Grin.
sp.p: 'Tis so, 'tis he; Give me thy hand ye Devil you, hark ye you serv'd me a plaguy trick, ye young Dog, but I can't be angry with thee for the heart of me, ha, ha, ha, ha— Well I'm in haste now, but I must Crack a Bottle with thee some time or other, for I can't be angry faith, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.p: No, so I ●ind; ha, ha, ha.—

sp.speaker: Darew.
sp.p: For fear of being beaten, ha, ha, ha,— 'tis such a grinning Puppy; and here comes another almost as bad; Oh my Lord, what you are hunting the Duck here, I suppose; Mrs. La Pupsey is in the next. Walk, she's div'd just before ye.

sp.speaker: L. Brain.
sp.p: A Pox take my Valet du Chamber, I should have been here half an hour ago, if the Rascal had Dress'd me sooner:— Prithee, Sir Philip how do'st like me, thou'rt a Man of Judgment; the Devil take me if I am not very much out of humour about it.

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.p: Why, what would you have my Lord? here's the Brandenburgh's Cut to a Hair, I see. The Walks begin to sill, here's Leviathan coming, and the rest of the fry, I shall be swallow'd if I stay, farewell: I'll go and sit an hour with my little dear at home, and keep my word with her like a Man of Honour. Exit.

sp.speaker: Darew.
sp.p: I had a Command from my Lady of the Lake too, to attend, she's somewhere in the Garden and I must follow her, tho' the dear damn'd Devil abuses me perpetually: 'Slise here she is— hah—
sp.stage: Enter Berenice, Solon, and La Pupsey.
sp.p: Sirrah, let go her hand, or I'll cut your Ears off before her Face.

sp.speaker: Solon.
sp.p: I won't, no, tho' you could Roar as loud as a Cannon, as a man may say.

sp.speaker: Darew.
sp.p: Why then I'll try if this can make ye, Rascal. offers to Draw.

sp.speaker: Beren.
sp.p: Do, Draw if thou darest, thou Rash, thou Cholerick Fool; draw but an Inch; nay, do but look as if thou wouldst, by all the Saints above, I'll discard thee for ever.

sp.speaker: Darew.
sp.p: Death, Hell, and Furies! you make me a mere Changeling.

sp.speaker: Beren.
sp.p: Why, then I make you what you are; and suppose you are Commanded to Act an Ass a little, will you refuse it to oblige your Mistress.

sp.speaker: Darew.
sp.p: To Rank me with such a thing as that, a Dolt, a Fool.

sp.speaker: Solon.
sp.p: Fool in your Face, Sir. Gadzookers, Madam, stand by and see fair play; you shall see me give the Captain a Salt-Eel: 'Slid I'll not be baffled by ne'er a Water Rat of 'em all, for now my blood's up I'll cut and slash, or go to Loggerheads with him if he dares.

sp.speaker: La Pups.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, This Fool will make rare sport; I'll improve it.

sp.speaker: Beren.
sp.p: D'ye hear, on my Conscience he'll beat thee.

sp.speaker: Darew.
sp.p: Oh Women, Women! what were Men born to suffer.

sp.speaker: Beren.
sp.p: To call a Gentleman Fool, a Man of his rare Qualifications; you shall see a spice of his parts, come Dance, Sir,— She Sings, he Dances awkwardly. Dance any thing Extempore.— There's a Lover for ye: So, now break a ●est, quick, quick, break a Jest.

sp.speaker: Solon.
sp.p: A Jest; why I say the Captain will never take a French Prize at Sea; because he's so ill at taking an English one ashore. there's a Jest for ye.

sp.speaker: Darew.
sp.p: Sordid Puppy.

sp.speaker: Beren.
sp.p: There's a Jest Extempore; that's more than the greatest Wit in Town can do, by this Light, Captain.

sp.speaker: Darew.
sp.p: Oons, d'ye call that a Jest.

sp.speaker: La Pups.
sp.p:
A Jest, Ay; and a good one too: Come now, Sir, as your last Tryal, Sing the Dialogue with me, that I shew'd you in the Arbor just now— Observe Captain.— Here they both Sing.
A DIALOGUE between Solon and Berenice.
Beren.
DAmon, if I should receive your Addresses;
What would you do to deserve my Embraces?
Solon.
If my dear Silvia would favour my Passion;
I would in faithful Love, Excel the Nation.
Beren.
I am Rich, Fair, and Young, Charming my Face is;
What merit can you boast to gain such Graces?
Solon.
I can Sing, Dance, Run, Leap, Wrestle, and Tumble;
And all the Day and Night be your most humble.
Beren.
Can you be patient, and Iealousie smother,
If you should Chance to see me Kiss another.
Solon.
I'm in good Nature all others exceeding;
And well acquainted too with your Town breeding.
Beren.
Or if before my Time you find me swelling;
Would you not grumble, nor think of Rebelling?
Solon.
I front my betters have learnt those Expedients;
And can by City Rule practise Obedience.
Beren.
Or if in Riot, Rich Cloths, or at Play still,
I lavish Thousands, yet would you Obey still?
Solon.
In living great you would add to my Fame too:
There's scarce a London Wife but does the same too.
Beren.
Take, Take my hand then, and straight let's effect it;
Thou art the very Fool I've long Expected.
Solon.
Let Fortune frown I can never miscarry,
For just such Fools as I are all that Marry.

sp.speaker: Beren.
sp.p: Very good; What think you now, Sir? Is this accomplish'd person a Fool? When will you do as much Captain?

sp.speaker: Darew.
sp.p: Well I'm fated to be the Fool my self; what would you have me say.

sp.speaker: Beren.
sp.p: Then live and learn, I mean more manners, Sir, than to question my behaviour; do that when you have power over me: Come, Sir.

sp.speaker: Darew.
sp.p: 'Dsdeath, you won't walk alone with him.

sp.speaker: Beren.
sp.p: Not alone with him; who told you so? Come worthy Sir.

sp.speaker: Solon.
sp.p: Gadzooks this is the Cricketty Minute, as my Brother Bias calls it: Lord how the Captain looks! as a Man may say. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Darew.
sp.p: Go and be dam'd; I'll plague my self no more; but only this, I'll beat that Fellow, present her with his Nose, and never see her after.

div.head: SCENE II.

sp.speaker: L. Subtle.
sp.p: Then dear Sir, or dear Madam, for I yet scarce know what to call ye, I am so transported with what you have told me, Will you promise to be true to me?

sp.speaker: Lovew.
sp.p: As your own Heart, Madam, you see before ye, a poor unfortunate Woman, abus'd beyond ●ufferance, by that worst of Monsters Sir Philip, the just Sence of which has rais'd my Spleen so high, that I will crack my Brain but be reveng'd, therefore once more assure your self, that as for his sake my Wit has us'd you ill, so for yours and my own, it shall make ample satisfaction.

sp.speaker: L. Subtle.
sp.p: Get but the Writings back— I'le wear ●hee here, here next my Heart, where thou shalt grow for ever.

sp.speaker: Lovew.
sp.p: I'll do't or dye— Have you seen Counsellor Splutter since we conferr'd last night together, he should have been here this Minute.

sp.speaker: L. Subtle.
sp.p: No, but have Fee'd him largely, not for his own, but to take thy Advice.

sp.speaker: Lovew.
sp.p: And he has done it faithfully, he has contriv'd the rarest new Deed about the Estate of Sir Solomon's Uncle, that died at Hamburgh, that our witty Knight will be so puzled about it, for I know his covetous Humor, and have accordingly fitted him; oh, here he comes, so Sir, you have dispatch'd I see.

sp.speaker: Splut.
sp.p: Ah Sir, you could not doubt that, when I was to serve so good a Client as my Lady, here's that will puzzle the Spark, or the Devil's in'●, but if this trick should fail, we have still another Game to play with him, for then I'll advise my Lady to go on with her Writ of Cozenage, 'gad there we'll trounce him.

sp.speaker: Lovew.
sp.p: No, prethee since Wit has begun, let Wit end it, and do thou but play thy part in bantring, as well as I have ●one in flatt'ring and fawning on him, 'tis impossible but we should succeed.

sp.speaker: L. Subtle.
sp.p: Does he swallow that Pill finely?

sp.speaker: Lovew.
sp.p: As I could wish, and now I don't touch upon Marriage, the lewd wretch is as kind to me, as he should really have been, had he done me Justice, whilst I degenerated by my wrongs, lie in his Arms and Plot like a true Jilt, and whilst he kisses me, vow dire revenge,— Hark, the Garden Bell rings, 'tis he, all away to your Post, and Lawyer— mind but your Cue, ne'r doubt the happy Issue, when I have finish'd the work this shall be the sign. whistles. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: L. Subtle.
sp.p: And if there be a happy Star for Widows, shine clear now I beseech thee. Exit.

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.p: How does my Blessing, what alone and melancholy, well, a pox take all Business I say, I had been with thee an hour sooner, but that the House of Commons sate so late, that

sp.speaker: Lovew.
sp.p: That you could not mind your Mistress, for minding the weighty Affairs of State, hah— If I had not help'd him out, that Lie would have made him black in the Face aside.

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.p:
Right Child, well but prethee, How go Affairs with the Widow,
hah, and the old Musty Knight, hast thou taken thy leave?

sp.speaker: Lovew.
sp.p: Speak softly, Sir, I have a Secret to tell ye.

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.p: A Secret, prethee what is't, out with't;

sp.speaker: Lovew,
sp.p: Come a little further from that Door there.

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.p: That Door, Why what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Lovew.
sp.p: Hush, softly I tell ye, hark in your Ear, Counsellor Splutter's in the next Room.

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.p: Counsellor Splutter, how so, nay your Footman can tell ye that he shew'd him up, for my part I absconded, twas not sit for me to be seen.

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.p: But prethee can'st tell nothing of the business?

sp.speaker: Lovew.
sp.p: Why, by what I over-heard, the Widow and he have had a difference about the Deed of the other Estate of Sir Solomon's Uncle at Hamburgh, which is in his possession, in which it seems you have likewise a considerable share, and the stingy Widow not giving a good Fee, I suppose he's come over to your side,— so that you are like to wallow in good Fortune now—

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.p: Dear dear lucky Rogue— 'tis thou art the cause of all, and I will so reward thee— well, I'll go to him—

sp.speaker: Lovew.
sp.p: Patience a little, Sir, there may be a trick in't, and he may chance to be a false Brother, and design to over-reach ye, now I have it in my Head, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.p: What, what, dear Rogue?

sp.speaker: Lovew.
sp.p: As for your good, Sir, I am still contriving. Fawning on him.

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.p: Sweet, charming, precious, prithee go on.

sp.speaker: Lovew.
sp.p: That if this Lawyer should prove a knave, which you know is no miracle.

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.p: No no, a Miracle, no no.

sp.speaker: Lovew.
sp.p: And you two should differ about Proposals, being possess'd of the Deed, having power to wrong ye; to prevent all, I have contriv'd that you should lock me into the Closset here, then bring him in to discourse the business over, so that I hearing every word between ye, may be a good Evidence in case of Knavery:

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.p: I gad, thou'rt in the right Child, why, thy Wit increases every Minute, it keeps no bounds, why this is the prettiest project to out-trick a Lawyer, here, get in quickly my dear, pretty Angel, faith thou tak'st too much care.

sp.speaker: Lovew.
sp.p: All for you sake, Sir. Clapping his Cheek●

sp.speaker: Si● Phil.
sp.p: I know it, and will be grateful to thee my Delight, my Jewel— there's no Service under Heaven that I would not do to oblige my Dear, Dear, Witty, Sweet, Kind, Lucky.

sp.speaker: Lovew.
sp.p: Will you Marry me, Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.p: Aw,— goe go, prithee get into the Closset Child, I'm afraid the Man of Law will bolt in upon us, and then our Plot's spoil'd.

sp.speaker: Lovew.
sp.p: D'ye keck still; I'll make ye glad to do't ere I have done with ye.

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.p: So now, I'm recover'd from my Fit again; He locks her into the Closset. that plaguy word comes always upon me, like an Eastern Wind, it blasts all my Joys in a moment,— now to my Lawyer, I hope there's another Estate coming, I shan't want a Witness, and I'm resolv'd I'll make him bawl loud enough.

div.stage: Re-enter Lovewell, with the Box of Writings, and Casket of Iewels.

sp.speaker: Lovewell.
sp.p: I have 'em once more, and to Sacred Fate, thus low I bow, with thanks for the Success: The Jewels too Man's glittering Opens the Casket damnation.

lg.l: Now Marriage-Hater, tho' I still must be,
Unhappy in my wrong'd Virginity;
I'll keep thee poor, thus I'm reveng'd of thee, Whistles and Exit.
I'll never pay thee for my Infamy.

div.stage: Enter Sir Philip, and Splutter with a Parchment.

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.p: Come Sir, here's a better light, pray speak out; I'd not give three half pence a Motion from this Lawyer, he'd not be heard two foot off in Westminster hall. aside.

sp.speaker: Splutter.
sp.p: She's gone, I heard the Sign,— aside.
Why truly, Sir, my Lungs are none o'th best— Ugh, Ugh— Coughs. but I'll read as well as I can, Sir,— and if you are the Heir at Law to this Estate—

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.p: Come, prithee begin; thou'rt a plaguy while about it;— Come, this Indenture.

sp.speaker: Splutter.
sp.p: This Indenture made the Fifteen Day of August, Anno. Dom. 1690.

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: So, now he Mouths it like a right Lawyer; the Devil's in't if she does not hear him now— aside.

sp.speaker: Splutter.
sp.p: In the Third Year of the Reign— but hark ye; before I go any further let's see the Will, to know whether your Name is Right here, I'll not read a Word more till I see that, you may be the wrong Person for ought I know.

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.p: Pox of his dilatory Impertinence; now must I go fetch the Writings out of my Closet.— How now, the Door open,— sure this Lawyer could not blow a Door open with his Bawling;— No, no, it maybe I slipt the Lock; I hope all's well within. Exit.

sp.speaker: Splutter.
sp.p: I, much good may't do ye with the Nest, the Birds are flown to my knowledge, and I'll after 'em; there's a Lawyers trick for ye. Exit.

sp.speaker: L. Subtle.
sp.p: Hast got 'em?

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Fast, fast, Madam; I've secured 'em for ye, where they shall never reach his Clutches more.

sp.speaker: L. Subtle.
sp.p: Oh thou dear life of all my Joys to come; what shall I do to shew my Gratitude.— Embracing her.

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.p: Robb'd, Cheated, Trick'd, Undone, by Heaven, not only the Writings gone, but Jewels too,— A plague of this Lawyer, and the Female Devil that set him at Work, where are they now— hah—

div.stage: Sees L. Subtle and Lovewell Embracing.

sp.speaker: L. Subtle.
sp.p: My Dear, Witty, Obliging— Kisses her.

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.p: The Widow here, nay then 'tis past Redemption; my Damnation is preparing and here are my Tormentors ready: Ah Fool, Fool, dull thoughtless Idiot.

sp.speaker: L. Subtle.
sp.p: Now for my Game with him; I'll try what Wit he has, now Fortune turns the Scale— Most Noble Sir, Charm'd with your Person, routed by your Wit; My Heart new Modell'd, and my Pride laid low, I'm contrary to Custom come to Wooe ye; and tho' a Widow, a mere Brokers-shop, that as you say put off Stale Wares for New, must beg ye to take up with an Old Suit, and Marry me whilst I am worth the wearing.

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.p: Oh!— Groans.

sp.speaker: Lovew.
sp.p: Or if you think a broken Virgin Better, that is as good a Maid as you have left her, and can make shift to Dine on a poor Joynt, that▪ you have made your Breakfast on before, Here I stand by you ready Cook'd and Dress'd, to be Cut up, Sir, by the Knife of Matrimony.

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.p: So, there's two Broad Arrows gone through my short Ribs already— such another Attack and I'm gone.

sp.speaker: L. Subtle.
sp.p: Tho' y'are possess'd of Seventy thousand Duckets, a mighty Sum in Jewels too, yet, Sir, in Charity you know—

sp.speaker: Lovew.
sp.p: Tho' loaded with your new Estate, in Hamburgh too, Sir, you should not slight poor me.

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.p: Ah Plague upon ye.

sp.speaker: L. Subtle.
sp.p: A young brisk Widow, is no Purgatory, Sir.

sp.speaker: Lovew.
sp.p: No, Sir, nor is the Property much alter'd in Virgins of my sort.

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.p: Ah, the Devil take your sorts— there's no remedy, I shall be worried.

sp.speaker: L. Subtle.
sp.p: Fie, fie, Sir, 'tis a shame to let us Court ye so, come, faith, say the word, shall we draw Cuts.

sp.speaker: Lovew.
sp.p: A short and a Long, Come, Sir, here's a slip of Parchment that ty'd the Box of Writings, this will do rarely. Takes up a slip of Parchment from the ground.

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.p: Ah stinging Devil.

sp.speaker: L. Subtle.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha,— he'll fall to my Lot, on my Conscience.

sp.speaker: Lovew
sp.p: Nay, that's Injustice, he should rather fall to mine to make amends for old scores,— What say ye, Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.p: Why, I say, that if ye don't both get ye instantly out of the Room, I shall beat ye.

sp.speaker: L. Subtle.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Lovew.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.p: A Plague on your Merriment, would the Devil had these Lodgings for being so near the Street, I'd try else if you would make another sort of noise.

sp.speaker: Lovew.
sp.p: That Lewdness has undone thee, impious Wretch, the scrowl of thy Offences are full numbred, and punishment pursues thy Guilt apace, canst thou look on me and not blush to death to see the Innocence, thy Vice has ruin'd; for tho' by Perjuries and Oaths betrai'd, I swear I was so innocent of Ill, I thought all Love like mine, was Honourable.

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.p: Wilt thou make me forget my self, Wilt thou not be gone, thou Witch thou Devil?— Consound 'em, What shall I do with 'em.

sp.speaker: L. Subtle.
sp.p: Now Sir, pursue your Marriage-hating Humor, Men of great Fortunes may do what they please,— Fool, thou shalt be my Days and Nights diversion, I'll never eat but the Theme of all the Jests, shall be Sir Philip's Wit, Sir Philip's Humor, and when I go to Bed, my very Woman— viewing the Jewels, shall even burst with Laughing, and cry out, Oh silly, silly, silly Marriage-hater.

sp.speaker: Lovew.
sp.p: And when I come to th' sport—

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.p: Why then a Legion comes, a thousand thousand, 'dsdeath, I shall draw upon 'em, if I stay, I've no patience lest. Runs and locks himself into the Closset.

sp.speaker: Lovew.
sp.p: Nay, I han't done with ye yet, Sir. Goes and Drums at his Door.

sp.speaker: L. Subtle.
sp.p: There's a Widow's Call to Marriage too, Sir, I know you love it dearly.

lg.l: Oh wretched Tribe, that dare that Law dispute;
Which does their Race distinguish from the Brute:
Lust was a Chaos, till the Great Creator,
Confin'd to bounds, the Wilds of Human Nature;
But this foul Beast as if of Bounds asham'd.
Defying Marriage, chooses to be Damn'd. Exeunt.

div.head: SCENE I.
div.p: SUre there never was so ●ond a fool as I, now the heat of my passion is over, I can't for the heart of me forbear coming back to make him another Proposal, he has us'd me barbarously, but then he has us'd me kindly too by sits, but then agen, the wrong he did me in getting me with Child, is insufferable,— ay, but then agen, 'twas with my own consent, but then 'twas monstrous in him to refuse to make me amends, ay, but how do I know but this last kindness may Convert him,— 'tis no imprudence to try him once more, Heaven may have chang'd his Mind. Sir, Sir,— a word wee.— Knocks softly.

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.p: How now, How dar'st thou come back t'abuse me, thou Sorceress, thou Thief, thou damn'd confounded plaguy Creature?

sp.speaker: Lovew.
sp.p: Alas dear Sir, why do ye wrong me so?

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.p: Dear Sir,— ah pox upon thee, dar'st thou mock me?

sp.speaker: Lovew.
sp.p: Not I upon my Soul, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.p: Or dost thou come back for my Cloaths and Money, thou hast not robb'd me enough, hast thou, thou Sybil.— Where are the Writings and the Jewels, Gipsey hah?

sp.speaker: Lovew.
sp.p: Pray be not angry, Sir, I have 'em safe.

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.p: Hah, Hast thou 'em,— have a care of Lying.

sp.speaker: Lovew.
sp.p: By all that's good I have, Sir, the Widow has not touch'd 'em yet.

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.p: How's this,— What a plague, this little Witch did not take 'em. by the way of frolick only, sure, 'dsdeath unriddle this quickly, I'm impatient.

sp.speaker: Lovew.
sp.p: You shall have 'em agen, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.p: Hah, What sayst thou?

sp.speaker: Lovew.
sp.p: You shall have 'em agen.—

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.p: Shall I,— Where, When, How? 'dsdeath don't tri●le with me.

sp.speaker: Lovew.
sp.p: From▪ me, Sir, from this Hand, this liberal Hand that gave away my Heart, shall give what you desire.

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.p: Then I'll believe thou lov'st me.

sp.speaker: Lovew.
sp.p: But you must Marry, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.p: Ugh, ugh, ●gh.— Coughs and Spits.

sp.speaker: Lovew.
sp.p: And that before hand too, else I am off the Bargain.

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.p: Art thou resolv'dd to Murder me?

sp.speaker: Lovew.
sp.p: Murder ye, sie, 'twill be a Health perpetual, all your life past has been perpetual hurry, lavish and wild, 'tis time, Sir, now to settle.

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.p: Settle, and Marry, So; there is, I remember, a third convenience belongs to't too.

sp.speaker: Lovew.
sp.p: You'll find your best Convenience is to do't Sir, take me, and take all; yet,— if not, Adieu t'ye, I shall make shift to save a Fortune out on't.

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.p: Let me consider, and ere I give my resolution fully, sum up the Catalogue of Marriage Evils.

sp.speaker: Lovew.
sp.p: Do, Sir, whilst I opposing answer with its Blessings.

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.p: Imprimis, to Marry ones Stale Mistress, ridiculous!—

sp.speaker: Lovew.
sp.p: Not when your Fortune's sunk, and she brings ye Thirty thousand pounds to build it up again.

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.p: Secondly, to feed still upon the same Dish, Morn after Morn, Night after Night.— Egud,— Kecks.

sp.speaker: Lovew.
sp.p: Wholesome, wholesome, 'tis the variety of Kickshaws that breed so many Diseases.

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.p: Thirdly, to be Forty times call'd Whoremaster, is not half so Igneminous as one Cuckold,— oh—

sp.speaker: Lovew.
sp.p: Nor is the plague of Cuckoldom half so Nauseous as that one Disease that attends the unfortunate Whoremaster.

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.p: Fourthly, to live like a Dog with a Bottle ty'd fast to his Tail, or an Ape with a great Clog on; Oh Intolerable!

sp.speaker: Lovew.
sp.p: Which you would never have done, if like an Ape you were not Mischievous, or did not like an unlucky Curr run after other Mens Sheep.

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.p: Then to have a useless Wife Puking— Ugh— an Impertinent Nurse a Snoring pugh— And a little squab Brat a Bawling,— Ugh, ugh, ugh,— Oh the Devil, I shall fetch my Lungs up, I shall never endure it. Coughs.

sp.speaker: Lovew.
sp.p: Why then, Adieu, I'll never ask ye more, I am resolv'd on't.

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.p: Stay— A lucky thought comes to me on the sudden, which if it take Effect, secures me yet— aside. Come hither again, where did you leave the Widow.

sp.speaker: Lovew.
sp.p: At the Streets end, with promise to come and deliver all up to her this Evening; and since you persevere thus in Injustice, I am resolved I'll do't,— She's so overjoy'd that she Intends to have the Musick and a Masquerade at her Lodging to Night; she will be grateful to me tho' you wont.

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.p: Come hither, thou hast won me, I will do't.

sp.speaker: Lovew.
sp.p: What? Marry me.

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
