sp.p: Pox, prithee name it by some other word, a Thunderbolt is not so dreadfull the plaguy Black Coat, shall do the plaguy business, if that's sufficient.

sp.speaker: Lovew.
sp.p: 'Tis all I wish; oh, how my Heart beats for Joy, this is the happiest Moment I e'er saw,—

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.p: I'll get a Parson and in an hour be with ye; till when, adieu: Ah little did I e'er think to be Fool'd thus.

sp.speaker: Lovew.
sp.p: Nor I to be so happy.— Exit Lovewell.

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.p:
Of what an odd kind of Composition is the Nature of Man:— If Consideration now could take place in me, I have no reason to deny doing Justice, to this pretty Creature, that is so kind, and can do me so much good, but on my Conscience, my only cause of hating a Wife, is, because it is convenient for me; and Marriage in those of my humour, is just like Devotion, Lov'd and Practic'd the less, because it is Enjoyn'd us; besides, being out-witted by this little Devil has so nettled me, that I cannot forbear putting one Trick more upon her, tho' 'tis unreasonable: Let me see, she will be Married before she
refunds,— Very good; why she shall,— and I think I have a Valet de Chambre can perform the Office as well as any Priest in Christendom; 'tis true, he's an Irishman, but a little sense will serve to do such a business.— Hey— Mack-Buffle.

sp.speaker: Buffle.
sp.p: Thy will, an't please thee.

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.p: Buffle, since this four or five days that thou hast been with me, I have received so good an Opinion of thy Wit, that I have now a project to Employ thee in.

sp.speaker: Buffle.
sp.p: I shall take Care of it to the besht of me Ability, if thou wilt be plain with me in the matter.

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.p: Why Mack, I must be Married, and I would have thee do the Office for me: Can'st thou read the Service, and Act a Parson rarely, hah?

sp.speaker: Buffle.
sp.p: Ee warrant thee, for ee have a Brother that is in Order, and ee have seen him do it so often, that ee cannot mistake.

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.p: That's well said, I'll fit thee with a Habit presently, and then do it but Cunningly and be the glory of thy Country.

sp.speaker: Buffle.
sp.p: I warrant thee, I warrant thee, my Father Teg was a cunning Scab before me.— Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Lovew.
sp.p: Tho' to oblige my self I must put this new Trick upon the Widow, yet I cannot in Conscience but contrive something to do her a kindness, and therefore resolve to manage the Old Knight's Nephew, the Flanderkin, till he is fit for my purpose, one Minute will do it, and then away brisk to my own Sir Philip; Hark, I think I hear him already. Noise within.

sp.speaker: Van Grin.
sp.p: within. Ha, ha, ha, ha,—

sp.speaker: Lovew.
sp.p: Ay 'tis he, and I believe laughing at his shadow for want of a better Subject,—
Oh Sir, you're come very opportunely— Pray what is't provokes your Mirth so.

sp.speaker: Van Grin.
sp.p: Why the oddest Jest that ever I knew in my Life, Faith and Troth, Ha, ha, ha, ha,— for upon the report of the Widows late good success you must know, I was making fresh Love to her, and running after her down a pair of Stairs, where the plaguy Jade her Maid, Ha, ha, ha,— had thrown a hand●ul of Pease just before; what does me I, but tumble down from Top to bottom Faith and Troth— Ha, ha, ha, Gad I believe I've broke two of my Ribs— besides, spraining my Leg, Ha, ha, ha, ha,— did you ever know such a ●est. Sits down.

sp.speaker: Lovew.
sp.p: No, by my Soul, never such a kind of Jest in my life.

sp.speaker: Van Grin.
sp.p: My Head too,— I've a knob in that as big as a Turkey Egg, Ha, ha, ha,— She told me before a Cannon shot would not break it, and now I find her words true Faith and Troth.

sp.speaker: Lovew.
sp.p: Oh Sir, 'tis a great sign of Love, when she begins to play Frolicks with ye.

sp.speaker: Van Grin.
sp.p:
Why faith, I think so, though she has been plaguy cross to me of
late too; but, if I thought this was her way of making Love, Gad I'd go a●● present her the use of my Legs and Arms, and let her sprain and break 'em as she pleas'd, let her but give me leave to Joke, and all the rest of my Members are at her Service, faith and troth, ha, ha, ha, ha, a very good Jest faith.

sp.speaker: Lovew.
sp.p: And truly, Sir, Yours is the most sensible sort of Love of any I ever heard of; for as a famous Author has it,

lg.l: He that Hangs, or beats out's Brains,
The Devil's in him if he feigns.

sp.speaker: Van Grin.
sp.p: Why 'tis very true; and that's very pretty,— and so art thou too, ye little brisk smug-fac'd Rogue, ha, ha, ha,— Oh my Ribs, my Side, my Legs,— ha, ha, ha,— a plaguy Jade, that was such a Jest to throw Pease upon the Stairs.

sp.speaker: Lovew.
sp.p: Ah Sir, thereby hangs a story that would make your Ribs soon well again, if you knew all.—

sp.speaker: Van Grin.
sp.p: Say'st thou so; prithee what is't? my dear Mercury.

sp.speaker: Lovew.
sp.p: Nay, I think in Justice I ought to inform ye; therefore know Sir, the Widow loves ye, and this Masquerade is I believe made chiefly for your sake.

sp.speaker: Van Grin.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha,— No, no, ye Jest, ye Jest.

sp.speaker: Lovew.
sp.p: Hush, lay your Finger upon your Mouth,— here comes Company; and if your Legs will give ye leave follow me, I'll tell ye more. Exit.

sp.speaker: Van Grin.
sp.p: 'Dsheart, if my Legs were off I'd follow thee upon this account.

sp.speaker: Darew.
sp.p: 'Dsdeath she has abus'd me beyond humane patience.

sp.speaker: L. Bum.
sp.p: Oh you must never mind that, Captain; 'tis the way of some Women; You a Man of War, and leave-off the Fight for a Chance shot or two, I'm asham'd on't,— When shall we sup together again, the last Venison was very good as I'm a Protestant.

sp.speaker: Darew.
sp.p: 'Twas a sign so by your Eating indeed.— aside.
Oh, when you please, Madam,— but hark ye, when is my Marriage to be.

sp.speaker: L. Bum.
sp.p: Why thou shalt have her to Night,— are the Hundred Guineas ready?

sp.speaker: Darew.
sp.p: All ready to Chink into your hand, Madam, if that were but done once.

sp.speaker: L. Bum.
sp.p: Thou shalt have her to Night then, I tell thee, she sent to thee to get a Parson ready, did not she.

sp.speaker: Darew.
sp.p: Why yes, and I have one yonder; but the Devil take me if I am not afraid she'll have some damn'd freak or other in her head, and plague me again; see yonder she comes, and that Fool Solon with her, whom I have not yet beaten; but if he scapes when next I meet him, I'll give him leave to Rival me indeed.

sp.speaker: Beren.
sp.p: Yonder he is, and I must teize him once more, tho' I lose him by't,— give me your hand, Sir, why d'ye loyter so,— You know I hate to have ye out of my sight; and yet you are still so backward.

sp.speaker: Darew.
sp.p: Fond, by this light, and blames him for his Loitering.

sp.speaker: L. Bum.
sp.p: She is not bewitch'd sure, is she.

sp.speaker: Solon.
sp.p: O Lord! I vow and swear, Madam, I could outrun the swift win●'d Racers of the Sky, as the Book says, to keep you Company, well, I vow that's a curious thought, as a Man may say.

sp.speaker: Darew.
sp.p: I shall have no patience,— Come Madam, what d'ye mean? the Man of God stays yonder according to your Order.

sp.speaker: Beren.
sp.p: Oh, thank ye good Captain; I had forgot I vow.

sp.speaker: L. Bum.
sp.p: Oh, she's coming to her self again, I see.

sp.speaker: Beren.
sp.p: Sir you are extremely oblig'd to the Captain here, for his good will, fearing that I should keep your passion off too long, he has provided here a Chaplain for ye— Come, Sir, I'm ready. To Solon.

sp.speaker: Darew.
sp.p: Death and Furies! a Chaplain for him.

sp.speaker: Solon.
sp.p: I Vow and Swear he's the Civillest person that ever I met in my Life, as a Man may say.

sp.speaker: Darew.
sp.p: Nay then, Rage shall take place; Scoundrel avaunt, and d'ye hear, Madam, do me Justice instantly, and come and let the Parson do his Duty, or may I live branded with the name of Villain, if here I throw not off all rules of Decency, Manners, Respect, and Duty for your person, and carve out instantly my worst Revenge in the Hearts blood of that ridiculous Monster.

sp.speaker: Beren.
sp.p: Why come then; Lord! what need you be in such a passion? If I must be yours, I must be yours,— and there's an end on't:— God buy Solon, you see there's no help sor't,— Betty stay here, and banter him as I instructed thee,— aside to Pimpwell. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: L. Bum.
sp.p: I was plaguily afraid the freakish Jipsey would have made me lose my hundred Guineas.

sp.speaker: Solon.
sp.p: A plague on't, what doings are here? Now foreward then backward; then this way, and then t'other way; now Chuck under the Chin, and next minute spet in ones Face; why this is the very Devil, as a Man may say.

sp.speaker: Pimp.
sp.p: Oh, Sir, don't trouble your self; this is only a trick upon the Captain; go presently and dress your self for the Masquerade, and then rely upon me; I'll give ye an account of her Habit, and you shall steal her off and Marry her in spite of him.

sp.speaker: Solon.
sp.p: Why then, I vow and swear, that will be mighty neatly contriv'd; and I shall have something in the bottom of my Pocket for thee too, Sweet-heart,— and if I can but steal her away as thou say'st, I care not if I go to Loggerheads with the blustering Captain every hour of the Day, as a Man may say.

div.head: SCENE. III.
div.stage: Enter Sir Lawrence and Bias in Masquerade; Sir Lawrence dress'd like an Old Woman.

sp.speaker: Sir Law.
sp.p: If I am not asham'd of my self; there is no Wisdom in Age and Experience; for an Old Man as I am, whose dress should be grave and decent, and whose Actions should be consequent to his Gravity, to come a Masquerading, Equipt thus egregiously: ah 'tis Foppish and Vile:— But then again, 'tis true, I'm a Courtier, and the Fop is the less seen in me.

sp.speaker: Bias.
sp.p: For my part I ne'er trouble my head about that, I'm no more a Fop now than I us'd to be.

sp.speaker: Sir Law.
sp.p: Ah Boy, 'tis for thy sake that I Expose my self thus; the Widow has receiv'd her Fortune again, I hear, and therefore we must turn the humour. Well Boy! but what Answer did she make thee this Morning.

sp.speaker: Bias.
sp.p:
Gad she was in the rarest humour that ever I saw her in my Life, faith;
she has appointed the hour, told me her Disguise, and I'm to steal her away to night n Masquerade.

sp.speaker: Sir Lawr.
sp.p: Why, Blessing on her Heart,— and my Opinion of her is mightily chang'd since yesterday— go go away Boy and watch her Motions— my Son.— Exit Bias. Solon will be provided for to night too, why, here will be such an hour of Coupling, gad, I believe the Stars themselves will be all in Conjunction, and I'm glad on't at my heart faith,— how now, who comes here— oh, I see the Humor holds general, there are more Fools abroad than my self.

div.stage: Enter Callow and Margery in Masquerade.

sp.speaker: Callow.
sp.p: So, My Dear, uow thou'rt mine by Law, the Parson has done his part— and I think I've done mine a little,— and faith to get up the Chimney to come out to me, was a very odd contrivance, that's the Truth.

sp.speaker: Marger.
sp.p: What d'ye think a Maid of my Age can't contrive to come out to her Man, when she hath a mind to be Married, I'd have broke thown the Wall but I'd have come to thee; if thwere only to spite my Father, I'll teach him to lock me up.

sp.speaker: Sir Lawr.
sp.p: That lisping Fool puts me in mind of my Peggy, that I have lock'd up at home.—

sp.speaker: Callow.
sp.p: Ay ay, now I have thee fast, let the old Heteroclite fret himself into a Consumption, if he will,— but see, here's some of the Masquers come already.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Oh Lord, that's an old Woman, I'll go speak to her,— How ●ow Grannum— What make you here, hah?

sp.speaker: Sir Lawr.
sp.p: I come a fooling as you do. What have you stole out from your Father's house, through the Chimney, say ye?

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Yeth that I have, and have Married without hith leave, becauth I sound my self capable.

sp.speaker: Sir Lawr.
sp.p: Indeed,— What! and you are the happy Bridegroom, are ye Friend?

sp.speaker: Callow.
sp.p: Instead of a better, Grannum, you will get little or nothing by us this time, we can bring our selves together without ye, we shall have no ocasion for a Bawd, Rot me.

sp.speaker: Sir Lawr.
sp.p: This must be the Rakehelly Lieutenant, I know him bp his Rot me.

sp.speaker: Callow.
sp.p: But if you have a mind to try, how you can move your old Bones, and will Dance at our Wedding, you must come away quickly, for we are just going to begin.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Ay ay, old Drybouth— we are Jutht going to begin, ha ha ha Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Sir Lawr.
sp.p: She has got my young Jades Tone exactly, by the Parliament I don't know what to think on't— if these young Queans can climb up Chimnies to get to their Fellows, what a plague signifies Locks to our doors,— I'll go afer 'em and be resolv●d, for my Heart misgives me damnably.— Exit.

div.stage: Enter L. Subtle, Sir Philip, and Lovewell in Masquerade.

sp.speaker: L. Subtle.
sp.p: Base ●aithless wretch, hast thou deceiv'd me then.

sp.speaker: L. Lovew.
sp.p: 'Tis in vain to rail, Madam, Sir Philip has done me right, and you must excuse me for frustrating your hopes upon so good an occasion; if we have wrong'd ye, you know the Law is open.

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.p: Ha ha ha— Here they are faith,— here's the glittering Damnation— come into my Clutches agen Widow. Shews the Iewels.

sp.speaker: L. Subtle.
sp.p:
And I hope she'll make thee pay for 'em,— and since merely to
abuse me thou hast Married— for still I know thou hatest it; May Discord, Jealousie, hated Barrenness, with all the Curses of the Marriage-State, be thy perpetual Plague.

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.l: Ay so it shall when I come into't,— aside.
this Crochet will do well upon my Hat, Widow,—

sp.speaker: L. Subtle.
sp.p: Out of my sight, or I shall Stab ye both.

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.p: Oh, nay, if you are so desperate, farewel t'ye,— come Lovewell, let's go and peruse our Writings. Exit.

sp.speaker: Lovew.
sp.p: Fie, fie, this Rage is ridiculous— what is done, is done, and tho' I cannot wrong my self, nor part with my dear Philip, nor his Fortune, yet if you'll follow my Advice, Madam, and Marry, I'll help ye to a Fool and Fifteen hundred a year, if that will make amends, nay, never boggle at it.— Keep up good Humor, let the Dance begin, and ere an hour is ended, he's your own.

sp.speaker: L. Subtle.
sp.p: Thou art a very Devil, and thou canst do any thing, there's no remedy, I see I must take what thou wilt give me, lead on. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Darew.
sp.p: So, with much ado, she's mine at last, tho' I was damnably afraid at first, all the time the Service was saying, that she would have plaid some freak or other with the Parson,— but, as it happens, she was more tame than I expected— well, Heaven send me good luck— I'm sure I've took pains enough about her.

sp.speaker: L. Brain.
sp.p: Who's that, Darewell?

sp.speaker: Darew.
sp.p: The same, my Lord, What is not the Dance begun yet?

sp.speaker: L. Brain.
sp.p: Begun, what, without me, Fool,— they may as well begin without the Fiddles; I have kept 'em a little too long, 'tis true, but what dost think I've been employ'd about?

sp.speaker: Darew.
sp.p: Nay, some mighty Affair, without doubt.

sp.speaker: L. Brain.
sp.p: The greatest in the World, the Devil take me,— thou art my Friend, I dare trust thee, hark in thy Ear,— I'm just now Married.

sp.speaker: Darew.
sp.p: Married, my Lord, why hark in your Ear then, So am I, this shall be call'd the Marriage Masquerade, for I know of two Couple more, but to whom good my Lord.

sp.speaker: L. Brain.
sp.p: Why▪ to dear Pupsey— I have been horribly in love with her a great while, thou know'●t she's an extreme witty person, and they say, a great Fortune.

sp.speaker: Darew.
sp.p: She has been a High Flyer indeed my Lord, and to my knowledge, kept company with Crown'd Heads, but not worth a Groat, by Heaven. aside.

sp.speaker: L. Brain.
sp.p: She's yonder amongst the Masquers, come Tarr, I believe thou'rt but a wooden Dancer,— Observe me and it may do thee a kindness.

div.stage: Enter Sir Philip, Sir Lawrence, Callow, L. Bum. Lovewell, Berenice, Solon, Bias, Margery, Comode, Pimpwell, Bandy, La Pupsey, L. Hockley in Masquerade; Pupsey carries her Lap-dog in Masquerade too.

body.head: SONG in Two Parts.
body.l: AS soon as the Chaos was turn'd into Form,
And the first Race of Men knew a good from a harm,
That the chiefest of Blessings were Women and Wine;
Since when by example Improving Delights,
Wine Governs our Days, Love and Beauty our Nights.
Of a Mystery out of our reaches;
Thô an Elder the contrary Preaches.
For never, my Friends, was an Age of more Vice,
Than when Knaves would seem Pious, and Fools would seem Wise.

sp.speaker: La Pup.
sp.p: Well, I swear your Lordship Dances like a little God.

sp.speaker: L. Brain.
sp.p: And thou like a Goddess, my dear charming Heavenly— ah Pox, there's no body else here can move a Leg,— yet saith the Masquerade is extravagant enough,— here's no body but Darewell, that I can guess at in the whole company— ha ha ha, I wonder who that bulky thing is.

sp.speaker: La Pupsey.
sp.p: That must be my Lady Bumfiddle by her Obessity.

sp.speaker: L. Brain.
sp.p: Her Obessity, What a Plague's that?— her Belly,— I see I must pick up my old scraps of Learning agen, my Spouse will over-run me else most damnably, but my Dear, prithee where's Monsieur Le Chien.

sp.speaker: La Pupsey.
sp.p: Oh my dear Dony, I had almost forgot him, I beg your Patience my Lord— I'll fetch him, and wait on ye agen immediately— Exit.

sp.speaker: Lovew.
sp.p: to Sir Phil.] So, by this time, Hymen has been Sacrific'd to sufficiently, no less than six Couple have lovingly paid their Devotion to his Altar, I'm sure.

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.p: Six Couple, why their off-spring well begot, in Twenty years time, may be enough to Man a Fleet— poor fool, there wants one Couple of the Six thô— to my knowledge— aside.

sp.speaker: L. Bum.
sp.p: The Devil take these Prolix doings, I begin to be very hungry.

sp.speaker: Beren.
sp.p: That's my Lady Bumfiddle, I wonder what she does for her Bumper all this while.

sp.speaker: Darew.
sp.p: She has been putting me in mind of Supper three times within this half Hour.

sp.speaker: Beren.
sp.p: If you were to ch●se— what you lik'd, which would you have of all these?

sp.speaker: L. Bum.
sp.p: There's nothing worth having here, but there's a Westphali● Ham and Pigeons in the next room, I'd chuse that if I might.

sp.speaker: L. Hock.
sp.p: This is somewhat rude La Pupsey, to your Betters, I must tell you that. Lady Pupsey justless Lady Hockley.

sp.speaker: L. Pupsey,
sp.p: my Betters, poor Creature, prithee my Lord tell her who I am, whilst I walk by and smile.

sp.speaker: L. Brain.
sp.p:
Madam, your Fault springs from your Ignorance, but hence●orth remember
this Lady is my Wife, Dammy.

sp.speaker: L. Hock.
sp.p: Why then, with my Lady's pardon,— I hope she'll thank me, at least, for all the old Gowns I've given her— for thô she be your Wife now my Lord, she was lately Retainer to our Caball, and formerly a Player.—

sp.speaker: L. Pupsey.
sp.p: The Devil was in me to provoke her, all will out now I see, there's no remedy.— aside.

sp.speaker: L. Brain.
sp.p: A Player, ha ha ha, why now you Rave, Madam,— Darewell, thou canst witness the contrary of that, thou toldst me her Breeding was such, that she has been familiar with Kings and Queens.

sp.speaker: Darew.
sp.p: Ay my Lord in the Play-house, I told ye she was a High Flyer too, that is, I have seen her upon a Machine in the Tempest.

sp.speaker: L. Brain.
sp.p: In the Tempest, why then I suppose I may seek her fortune in the inchanted Island, what a plague you have trick'd me then Fubbs, have ye?

sp.speaker: L. Pupsey.
sp.p: Trick'd ye my Lord, that's a phrase I confess I understand not yet, but if you design to be Acid, I can have patience thô you are never so Acrilogical, 'tis all one to me, 'tis the same thing in the Greek. Enter Van Grinn.

sp.speaker: L. Brain.
sp.p: Greek, the Devil▪ take all Learning, I say, 'dsdeath are these the joys of Marriage?

sp.speaker: Van Grin.
sp.p: The Joys of Marriage, ha ha ha ha, a very good Jest, faith; I have most share in that, I'm sure. Where is this Sir Philip, now let him produce himself, that I may laugh at him immoderately, ha ha ha ha, for I have Married the Widow and wip'd his Nose, Faith and Troth, ha ha ha.

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.p: Thou hast got indeed the Shell of the Widow, but her Kernel, the Writings and Jewels are under Lock and Key in my ●ustody, ha ha ha ha.

sp.speaker: Van Grin.
sp.p: He's downright Mad, Faith and Troth,— thou the Jewels, speak Spouse, and consute the silly Knight—

sp.speaker: L. Subtle.
sp.p: Why, the Truth is, Sir, he has got the Writings and Jewels agen; but now I have got you with an Estate, Sir, we'll swinge him off at Law.

sp.speaker: Van Grin.
sp.p: Law!— nay, if you talk of Law already, I've catch'd a Tartar faith and Troth.

sp.speaker: Sir Lawr.
sp.p: Sure my Eyes don't dazle. What can be the meaning of this?

sp.speaker: Bias.
sp.p: What a Plague, is the Widow split in two then? for I have one half of her here.

sp.speaker: Comode.
sp.p: Not half a Widow, but a whole Maid at your Service, Sir.—

sp.speaker: Lovew.
sp.p: Oh! Mrs. Comode, I wish ye much Joy.—

sp.speaker: Sir Lawr.
sp.p: Why, this is Witchcraft, by the Parliament, now I'm serious.

sp.speaker: Bias.
sp.p: What a pox have I got, the Widows Bed-warmer, and instead of 70000 Ducats, the lawful Inheritrix to 7 pair of worn-out Lac'd Shooes, and a Dozen of old Combs; go Troop Troop, my Brother Solon will laugh me to death,— he has got a ●ine Lady and a Fortune. Pushes Comode away.

sp.speaker: Darew,
sp.p: Not the Lady you mean I can assure ye Sir, as this can witness, I have laid her aboard my self.— Discovers Berenice.

sp.speaker: Solon.
sp.p: Why then, as I hope to be sav'd, I can't tell what to make of all this, I was to take her away in this disguise, and now he has got her, and if I han't Married her, I'll take my Oath on't I've Married the Devil in her shape, as a Man may say.

sp.speaker: Pimpw.
sp.p: You have Married one, Sir, that has had a tender care for your Person a long time, I assure ye— Discovers her self.

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.p: Ha ha ha— Here's Matrimony like Grapes in Clusters, Faith— I'm glad I've 'scap'd squeezing. aside.

sp.speaker: Beren.
sp.p: Oh Betty, I wish thee good luck, take care and make a good Wife, d'ye hear?

sp.speaker: Solon.
sp.p: You have neither good Bubbies nor a good Face,— therefore Troop Troop, as my Brother Bias says. Pushes Pimpwel away.

sp.speaker: Comode.
sp.p: Well Sir, the Law will give us Allie Money, and that's all we care for—

sp.speaker: Sir Lawr.
sp.p: My two Sons Married to two Chamber-maids— and by a Trick,— nay then, there seldom comes two Mischiefs but there's a Third,— by your leave Mistress— I believe you and I have some intimacy— Vnmasques Margery.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Well well, what care I, heerth my Huthband— And y'are an old fribling, fulsome, foolish, feeble, fumbling fornicating Fellow, for all y're my Father, to lock up me, tho ye are.

sp.speaker: Sir Lawr.
sp.p: Ay, i knew 'twas she— here's your coy, skittish Quean for ye,— they're all so, they Sneak and Prim in publick, as if Butter would not melt in their Mouths, but they are very Devils in a corner.

sp.speaker: Callow.
sp.p: Well well, Sir, pay her her Six thousand pounds— and then Rail as much as you think good, Rot me.

sp.speaker: Sir Lawr.
sp.p: D'ye hear Friend, you know y'are a Coward, and I know y'are Cashier'd, and therefore if you get one farthing of her Fortune, why then— Rot me.

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.p: He's in the right Callow; your business is done at Court, I told ye what would come of your herding with the Factious Party.

sp.speaker: Darew.
sp.p: Why now, one may walk Horses, and t'other may Spin, a very hopeful Match indeed.

sp.speaker: L. Bum.
sp.p: There never comes better luck when the Blockheads don't Consult me, I have always observ'd it as I'm a Protestant.

sp.speaker: Callow.
sp.p: 'Tis very hard they should pick out only me, there are more Officers in the Regiment, and some, ●hat to my Knowledge, how faïr soever they carry it, are as Factious as my self, Burn me.

sp.speaker: Lovew.
sp.p: And by degrees will be all glean'd out I hope,— A R●t in an Army is a dangerous thing— but Sir Lawrence, Have your new Affairs intirely taken up your Memory, that you forget your Servant Lovewell.—

sp.speaker: Sir Law.
sp.p: Lovewell, I'm amaz'd, why thou look'st like a very Woman.

sp.speaker: Lovew.
sp.p: And as very a Woman I am, old Knight, as ever you knew in your life, that has, to right former Injuries, and help the Marriage-hater here to a good Wife, that may be the occasion of his Salvation hereafter, liv'd thus long in disguise in your Family, and instead of Brother to your Friends Daughter Phaebe, that was debauch'd, you here behold the very Phaebe her self, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Law.
sp.p: H● day! why this is an hour of Wonders.

sp.speaker: L. Bum.
sp.p: The Marriage-Hater Catch'd at last, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: L. Hock.
sp.p: The Marriage-Hater Catch'd at last, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Sir. Phil.
sp.p: Hold, hold, good Ladies,— pray let me Explain my self a little, lest your Extravagant Mirth should not hold out well to the end; 'tis true my Dear, as thou say'st, I am Married.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Ay, Child, I know it; and thou hast made me the happiest Creature breathing.

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.p:
With all my Heart; would I could marry fifty a day at the same rate, for such a Fortune,— Buffle, come Sirrah, off with your Disguise; Look ye, Child,— resolving not to let any Female Wit ever have the better of me; I have over-reach'd thee with another trick, faith, and a● Married by my Valet
de Chambre; so that, instead of dull, drowzy Wedlock, I am just in the Predicament as I was before, ha, ha, ha, ha,— Turns back on the sudden, and finds Thum. instead of Buffle.
How now! What a Devil art thou.—

sp.speaker: Thum.
sp.p: A Minister of the Word▪ and shall please thee.

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.p: A Minister; what a plague have I to do with a Minister?— where's Buffle?

sp.speaker: Thum.
sp.p: He is at the Door there; he did desire me to do for thee this good office.

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.p: Peace Hell-hound, Screech-Owl, Black-Coat, Slave,— by the Furies I'm caught in my own Snare.— aside. Enter Buffle.
How now, Rogue; what mistake is this?

sp.speaker: Buffle.
sp.p: I desire thou wilt not be angry, I have done all for thy good indeed.

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.p: Ah sordid Villain, I'll Murder thee— Pulls Buffle by the Ears and Cuf●s him.

sp.speaker: Darew.
sp.p: Oh, prithee, Sir Philip,— no Passion now; let's hear what the Fellow says.

sp.speaker: Buffle.
sp.p: Why, what is there occasion for all this broken Face now; have ee not done all things for the besht, indeed;— thou didst deseer me to learn the way of the Marriage, for thee; and by Chr●esht ee did learn and learn, and ee did forget again indeed;— and then for fear that I should mistake ee did desee● my Brother, who is in Orders, and whose Trade it is— instead of my shelf, to do it well for thee; and vare is the harm of this.

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.p: Hell and the Devil! Oh Ignorant Dog; that I could but get at that Nose of thine.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Go, go, get ye both gone; and here's twenty Guineas to Cure your Face, Friend; away I say,— Exeunt Buffle and Thummim.
'Slife how near had I been lost again; this is the luckiest turn that ever happen'd.

sp.speaker: L. Brain.
sp.p: Faith, Freewit, thou'rt snapt too,— thou'rt in our Row now, in spite on thee, I'm glad he has married his Wench, that he mayn't laugh at me for my bargain there,— for the Devil take me, if I don't begin to be asham'd of her already. aside.

sp.speaker: Sir Law.
sp.p: Well, for my part, since Chance must rul● the Roast in spite of all Endeavours, I'll be a fond doting Fool no longer,— Let my Son Bias be Pox'd if he pleases; my hopeful Son Solon hang himself in his hopeful Wifes Garters, and let my Daughter turn Doll Common to the Army:— I'll please my self as long as I can by the Parliament; keep a good Table to get me Reputation; drink the King's Health to shew my Loyalty▪ keep a good Horse in my Stable, and a hand●ome Wench for my House-keeper, and there's the resolution of an old Courtier; now I'm serious in good Earnest.

sp.speaker: Bias.
sp.p: Say ye so old Dew-beater; why then I'll do like all those Sons whose Fathers are● as you have been,— Spend all I can in your Life time; Drink Bumpers to your good passage, when I hear you are dying; and forget ye before ye are buried.

sp.speaker: Solon.
sp.p: I'm sure 'tis you have been the occasion of my miscarriage; for you would have me Marry, tho' I was no more fit for a Wife, ●han a Cow is for a Saddle, as a Man may say.

sp.speaker: Beren.
sp.p: Come Sister, what grown dull with your new Fortune? You may be glad it happens so well; Come, come, be merry for shame, and Cheer up your Husband there, I swear he's down in the Mouth.

sp.speaker: L. Subtle.
sp.p: And will be worse down, I believe, before I've done with him.— Why, it seems he had the Impudence to expect a Fortune with me; 'tis a Proverb indeed; ●hat often by Chance, Fools may have Fortune;— but that a Widow ever gave a Fortune to a Fool, is a President yet to make, at least till she was come to her time of dotage:— Come, come, Laugh, Sir, Laugh.

sp.speaker: Van Grin.
sp.p: This is the only thing in the World that I can't Laugh at, Faith and Troth; First, to Marry one that cares not if I were hang'd; and then to be frustrated of her Fortune, which is the only thing a Widow is good for; one too that has the Impudence to ●●ll me Fool the first minute of our Marriage, and without doubt will make me a Cuckold the next; t'has quite balk'd me; I could not Laugh if I might get a thousand pounds by't,— I could rather weep, faith and troth,— makes Grimaces as ready to weep.

sp.speaker: Darew.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, ha,— a pox on't you must strive against Melancholy, Man,— 'tis the worst disease for a fellow of thy Kidney in the World; besides to begin with it, upon thy Wedding-day, 'tis ominous; for my part I have been venturing too here, but am resolved to be merry, come what will on't.

sp.speaker: Beren.
sp.p: You shall have no cause to be otherwise, Sir, all my freaks are now ended, they were only to try your humour, Sir, and have all made their Exit with my change of Condition; I am now as tractable a plain dull silly House-dove, as if I had been in twenty Sea-sights with ye, or had come under your Lee, for as many Years.

sp.speaker: L. Brain.
sp.p: Well! what fortune I shall get by my Marriage, I find is a Riddle, but I am sure to have Rhetorick in abundance,— if slorid words could be sum'd into pounds, I were certain of Ten thousand of 'em in an hours time:— I hope Madam, I may take place of Monsieur L'Chien too; 'tis time for our Rivalship to end now.

sp.speaker: La Pupsey.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord, says he, I shall be proud to yield to your Lordship in any thing says he, yet I have had many a sweet Night with my dear says he, Ay my dear Life's-blood so thou hast.— Well! my Lord may be as angry as he pleases— but if I've a hundred Children by him, I shall ne'er love one of 'em half so well.— apart.

sp.speaker: L. Bum.
sp.p: Why, what a glut of Weddings are here,— and but one Supper to 'em all, this is pittiful Management, as I'm a Protestant.

sp.speaker: L. Hock.
sp.p: I vow, I could wish, methinks, the Frolick had gone thorough; my Niece and I here, are the only uncoupled in the whole Company.

sp.speaker: Bandy.
sp.p: Which was neither of our faults, Aunt, I'm sure.

sp.speaker: Darew.
sp.p: Come, ●●r Philip; Fate is Inevitable, and 'tis in vain to resist its decree, for my part I'll wear my Yoak, if it chance to be a Yoak, with all the Patience imaginable;— and when the Marriage Courtship is a little over, to Sea again, and Court the Foe in Thunder,— Our Fleet is Royal, Hearts I hope are found too;

lg.l: And let our Loyal Union, be well fram'd;
If ever then we are baffled, I'll be damn'd.

sp.speaker: Lovew.
sp.p: And now, Sir, passion being a little over, I hope you'll own what I have done was just; and since to help the failures of my Wit, a special Act of Providence befriended me, be pleased to look on me with Eyes of Pity,

lg.l: For you might have, Sir, to Indulge your life,
A new●r Bride, but not a better Wife.

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.p: Give me thy hand,— I am Convinc'd this moment, that Marriages the Bliss or Plagues of Life, are as thou say'st, all th' Effects of Providence; and to begin the Reverend Estate Soberly,— first I will Execute Justice; Therefore, as to you, Madam,— To L. Subtle. what of Sir Solomon's Estate appears your due, shall justly be surrender'd.— My Spouse, and I shall have enough to Eat with, and cooly enjoy our selves like old Acquaintance, that long have fed on the Bak'd meat of Matrimony: And since the Stars, with their propitious Influences, in spite of my Opinionated Wit, have us'd me like a Vermine in a Trap,

lg.l: Patient, I'll Rellish pleasure dearly bought,
And Chaw on the same Cheese, with which I'm caught.

div.head: EPILOGUE.
div.stage: Spoken by La Pupsey, with her Lap-dog in Masquerade.
div.l: TWo Heads they say are best, I and the Dog
Ioyn therefore, to perform the Epilogue:
And first, before we excuse what th' Poet Writ,
Your humble Conge, Dony, to the Pit. Bows the Dog.
Gallants, says he, I must presume to Crave
The Privilege that all Young Actors have;
Who tho they often blunder to a Crime,
Are certain of your pardon the first time.
And tho' I want the Management of Tongue,
And have said little, yet you know I've Sung.
Ay, so thou hast my dear Felicity: Kisses him.
So much for Dony, now the rest for me.
I Swear, I quake to think, tho' not intended,
How many here may chance to be offended;
Who often when their Lovers can't succeed,
Smuggle a Creature of my Dony's breed.
For as a Babe of Seven,
To imitate the Married Couples Brood,
Will play with their resemblance made in Wood,
So Infants of Eighteen that want success,
To Catch the greater Donys play with less.
This amongst others, Gallants, to your view,
We now present ye all as humours new;
Without the least reflection or Abuse:
And if you now Impartial Candor use,
Then to your Service we shall still apply
Your most Obsequious Humble Dog and I.

div.head: PROLOGUE. Mr. Monford Enters, meets Mrs. Bracegirdle dressed in Boy's Cloaths, who seeing her, Endeavours to go back, but he taking hold of her, Speaks:

sp.speaker: Monf.
sp.l: NAY, Madam, there's no turning back alone;
Now you are Enter'd, faith you must go on;
And speak the Prologue, you for those are Fam'd,
And th' Play's beginning.

sp.speaker: Brace.
sp.l: Would the Play were Damn'd:
I shall ne'er wish the Poet good Success;
For putting me into this nauseous Dress;
A Dress, which of all other things I hate;

sp.speaker: Monf.
sp.l: That's very strange, faith, since thy Legs are straight;
For if thou hadst a thousand Lovers here,
That very Garb, as thou dost now appear
Takes more than any Manto we can buy,
Or Wir'd Comode, tho' Cock'd Three Stories high,

sp.speaker: Brace.
sp.l: I hate this Coat, this Masculine Hat too here,
These Breeches, and the other things I wear.

sp.speaker: Monf.
sp.l: Not all things, Madam, now y'are too severe
When the Disguise, no lewdness does expose:
Breeches, as Modestly themselves disclose,
As Petticoat that reaches to your Toes.

sp.speaker: Brace.
sp.l: Let all loose Dresses to loose Minds belong,
Men, nor their Garbs did e'er my Credit wrong.

sp.speaker: Monf.
sp.l: That's much faith having known the Stage so long.
Well, we'll allow your Modesty is Fam'd,
Come now,— the Prologue.

sp.speaker: Brace.
sp.p: Lord, I'm so asham'd.

sp.speaker: Monf.
sp.p: A Player, and asham'd, that may be true.

sp.speaker: Brace.
sp.p: You think sure I'm as impudent as you.

sp.speaker: Monf.
sp.l: No Child; you would not do then as you do;
You would not lose a Fortune for a Toy,
Nor frown nor blush whene'èr you Act a Boy;
Or speak a Prologue, which you must do now,
And to assist you see, I'll make your Bow. Bows to the Audience.

sp.speaker: Brace.
sp.l: Well Gentlemen, since then do what I can,
Spite of my self, I must appear a Man;
Pray let me beg ye▪ not to like me less
Than when you see me in my Maiden Dress;
And free from Amorous Censure this one day
For my sake spare the Poet and the Play.
For to speak Truth in its incouragement,
There is a Plot, and some good Humor in't:
The Ladies too must needs approve the Matter,
Because be punishes the Marriage-hater.
And if you bring good Humor, you shall laugh,

sp.speaker: Monf.
sp.p: Why, that's well said my Dear, and so let's off. Exeunt.

div.head: A Scotch Song in the Third Act.

lg.head: I.
lg.l: BOnny Lad, prithee lay thy Pipe down;
Tho' blith are thy Notes they have now no power:
Whilst my Ioy my dear Peggy is gone,
And Wedded quite fro me will Love no more.
My gud Friends that do ken my grief,
With Songs and Stories, a Cure would find:
But alas, they can bring no relief,
For Peggy still runs in my mind.

lg.head: II.
lg.l: When I Visit the Park or the Play,
They âw without Peggy a Desart seem;
She's before my Eyes aw the Day,
And aw the long Night too, she haunts my Dream.
Sometime fancying a Heaven of Charms,
I wake, and Rob'd of my dear delight,
Find she Ligs in anothers Arms:
Ah then 'tis she kills me outright.

lg.head: III.
lg.l: Take my Counsel aw you that love well;
Bestow Love and Wit on a Girl of Sense:
No such Blessing to Peggy befel,
'Twas Ignorance caus'd her absurd offence.
She could pray with an humble face;
And look as she never false could be:
But had she own'd either Wit or Grace,
She never had Wedded fro me.
